column1: The main goal of this project was to develop an integrated aquatic vegetation management plan for Mason Lake that includes aquatic plant survey, education, and recommended strategies to eradicate/contain milfoil populations.

column1: Mason Conservatoni District will try a variety of control methods including hand removal, covering with bottom screening, and various aquatice labled herbicides to determine the best way to control the growth of this weed in Mason Lake.
column2: Mason Conservation District used a variety of methods to control/eradicate Slender Arrowhead.  Volunteers removed Slender Arrowhead by hand pulling.  volunteers and contractors also placed 28,500 sq. ft. of bottom barrier fabric, anchored with sandbags.  Bottom barriers were estimated to be about 80% effective after two years of coverage.  Mason Conservation District experimented with three different aquatic herbicides to control the plant. Reward (diquat dibromide) worked well to control the submerged vegetation, but did not affect root corwns, tubers, or rhizomes.  Sonar (flouridone) provided excellent control in the laboratory, but no control in the lake. Lake residents designed and used an annovative tent-like structure to contain the herbicide around the target plants, but the herbicide was still ineffective.  Rodeo (glyphosate) only controls plants that extend above the water line (though it controls them very well).  Little of the Slender Arrowhead in Mason Lake extends above the water line sufficiently to allow foliar application of this herbicide.  At the beginning of the project, the recipient estimated that Slender Arrowhead covered about 4.5 acres of the littorial area of Mason Lake.  At the end of the project, the doverage was estimated to be about 1.0 acre.  The recipient was optimistic that 90% of the remaining infestation would be controlled/eradicated through the use of bottom barriers.

column1: THIS GRANT PROVIDES $36,000 TO CONTINUE THE MILFOIL ERADICATION EFFORT IN MASON lAKE BY INSTALLING BOTTOM BARRIERS AND HAND PULLING.
column2: Water Quality and Environmental Outcomes The areas of Mason Lake infested with milfoil remained about the same when comparing the 2007 and 2010 survey/treatment maps. However, the density of the infestation has been reduced.  The Mason Lake group has concluded that they have developed an effective approach to controlling, but not eradicating, this aquatic weed.Performance Items and Deliverables The grant recipient completed all of the performance items, and Ecology received the required deliverables. Key among these items were:•	Surveying the littoral zone of the lake and identifying milfoil locations.•	Using a combination of professional and volunteer labor for control efforts (placing bottom barriers, hand pulling, and applying herbicides).•	Maintaining a high level of public awareness of the milfoil infestation and control effortsAdditional Comments: This project was envisioned as primarily one of installing bottom barriers and using hand pulling for weed control. The scope of work was modified to include using spot treatment with herbicides for areas that could not be controlled with bottom barriers or hand pulling.

column1: The Mason Conservation District will use the money to encourage local involvement in the process to assist the Department of Ecology in the development of the detailed implementation plan for the Todd/Eld Inlet Total maximum daily load.  The district will also facilitate water quality monitoring within the watershed, study the effectiveness of best management practices (BMPs) implemented in the 1990s, develop a solid LID Implementation tracking and follow-up program, establish an 'Early Contact' program for the conversion of large tracts of land into potential small non-commercial livestock keeping operations, and conduct outreach programs to educate the landowners within the project area on the use of BMPS for both agricultural practices and on-site system operation and maintenance.  The Mason Conservation District will also work with landowners to develop new farm management plans.
column2: Thurston County Dept. of Public Health performed water quality monitoring to investigate pollution problems identified during the Dept. of Health's 2004 Shoreline Survey of the Eld Inlet Shellfish Growing Area.  A detailed detailed report of the activities they accomplished under this project was provided as part of the final reporting requirements.  All monitoring data was submitted into the EIM database.  The County also participated in the DIP/SIS process.  In addition to the follow-up in the Eld Inlet basin, water quality monitoring was also accomplished in McClane, Schneider, and Kennedy Creeks.  Very few compliance issues were identified.  All agricultural sites were referred to Thurston CD.  Suspect septic systems were dye traced and none were found failing.  Dog waste was identified as a potential pollution source in the Sunset Beach neighborhood, but was dealt with through a partnership of Thurston County and a neighborhood resident.  A letter identifying the problem and asking for compliance was sent and the resident installed dog poop baggie stations and distributed educational brochures. Mason CD convened and facilitated the Totten/Eld Technical Advisory Group meeting with input from affected local agencies and local citizens.  They worked with Ecology staff to draft a Water Quality Implementation Plan.  Farm planning efforts from the mid-90's were evaluated and deemed effective and still providing benefit to the properties and to water quality.  An inventory of BMPs implemented during inactive grant periods was developed and provided as part of the final reporting requirements.  Agricultural inventories were updated in both Thurston and Mason County portions of the watershed.  Thirty-seven farm plans were developed and/or updated.  A BMP implementation tracking and follow-up program was developed.  Mason CD assisted 62 landowners in implementing 123 BMPs.  Ecology approved BMPs were designed and implemented with technical assistance from Mason CD through new and updated farm plans.  the BMPs implemented included: 2 acres of tree and shrub establishment, 4,925 feet of riparian fencing, and 22 acres of riparian forest buffer.  Thirty-nine workshops were conducted with a total of 933 participants.  Twenty-three press releases to local media advertising the workshops and providing education to readers on water quality issues in the watershed were done.  Two newsletters for Griffin Elementary School parents were produced and distributed.  Seventy-five radio spots on the Garden Gate radio show (KMAS) featuring timely water quality issues were produced.  Educational materials were distributed at 24 local events.  A direct mailing was produced and sent to 600 watershed residents.  Water quality education was provided to youth on 34 different occasions.

column1: The Mason County Public Works Department will use the money to develop stormwater management plans for the communities of Belfair and Hoodsport and also the development of a county-wide comprehensive stormwater program for Mason County.  In addition, a small stormwater quality enhancement project in the Belfair area benefiting the canal will also be implemented.  Project efforst will improve overall stormwater managerment efforts in Mason County and will assist in the reduciton of stormwater loading to Hood Canal.
column2: A stormwater management plan for the Belfair Urban Growth Area was developed and the Mason County Commissioners adopted this plan through Ordinance #180-07.  A stormwater management plan for the Hoodsport Rural Activity Center was developed and the Mason County Commissioners adopted this plan through Ordinance #119-08.  A county-wide stormwater management plan was developed and the Mason County commissioners adopted this plan through Ordinance #33-09.  A water quality enhancement project was planned and implemented in the Belfair area that used a combination of bioswales and mycofiltration to treat stormwater.  The mycofiltration approach consisted of burlap bags containing wood chips which were inoculated with mycelium (fungus). Individual microfiltration bags, ranging in number from 20 to 60, were installed at five locations.  Monitoring results showed fecal coliform reductions below the installation at three of the four sites tested.  No results were available for the fifth site as dry conditions were encountered.  The county concluded that this is a very cost-effective and time- effective way to provide treatment for surface stormwater flows.

column1: Kitsap County will use the money for an innovative pilot project, which provides financial assistance to private citizens for the repair or replacement of failing on-site sewage systems in the Hood Canal region.  This innovative partnership will be based on an inter-local agreement between Jefferson, Mason, and Kitsap counties and Port Gamble S'Klallam and Skokomish tribes and will utilize a private non-profit community development lending institution to provide a "one stop" financing program to homeowners for on-site septic system repairs.
column2: This grant funding made possible development of a permanent lending mechanism built through a public/private partnership.  An Advisory Board with public health and lender representatives produced formal program guidelines and lending policies, developed and carried out a marketing plan, and continues to oversee the lending activities undertaken by the non-profit lender.  Funding of the improvement loans was shared between this grant source and private loan capital held by the non-profit lender on a 62.5 percent public/37.5 percent private basis.  The project did not accomplish any on-site system repairs within the Port Gamble S’Klallam or Skokomish Tribal reservations. The homes and facilities on the Skokomish Reservation are all monitored by tribal staff and receive design services and financial assistance for repairs through the U. S. Indian Health Service.Water Quality and Environmental Outcomes The anticipated project outcomes included replacement of on-site systems, financial assistance to distressed homeowners, and education for system owners about proper operation and maintenance of their sewage systems, all of which would lead to improved water quality in water courses and marine waters.  The recipient made 40 system repairs funded with grant dollars. While this project did not include water quality monitoring, ambient stream monitoring data provided by the Kitsap County Storm and Surface Water Management Program indicated improvement in fecal coliform levels in some streams where on-site system repairs were made in their up gradient watersheds.  Performance Items and Deliverables The key deliverable was a revolving loan mechanism that incorporated outreach and education elements. Kitsap County contracted with ShoreBank Enterprise Cascadia (EC) for development and operation of the lending mechanism. EC established an advisory body which guided program policies and procedures and provided oversight throughout the term of the project.   EC produced marketing materials used by local health professionals, environmental educators, and private sewage contractors for outreach to system owners.  In addition, EC created a website that contains information and allows for completion of an on-line loan application.  During the project period, 164 owners made inquiries about repair loans and 101 applications were received; 50 applications were approved and 40 repairs completed with regulatory approval.  The lender provided quarterly reports containing information on system location, condition, repair components, and project costs.  Thirty-six percent of the 50 approved loans were made to those with incomes less than 60 percent of the median family income for the three county area; 56 percent to those with incomes under 80 percent.  To encourage continuing operational and maintenance attention to the improved on-site sewage systems, EC included a periodic maintenance requirement in the loan documents and provided an option for additional borrowing up to $1,750 over five years following completion of repairs to fund system monitoring and maintenance.     Additional Comments: Ambient monitoring by local jurisdictions will help to inform the question of measurable water quality impacts for programs like this one.  Positive outcomes would include reduced levels of fecal coliform in streams, or along marine shorelines, and upgrades in classification of shellfish harvest areas.

column1: Two high-visibility projects will demonstrate stormwater management near impaired water bodies of statewide significance.  Projects at Pioneer School and Turning Pointe Domestic Violence Shelter will demonstrate various low impact development best management practices including permeable parking surfaces, rain gardens, and biodetention.
column2: Prior to construction of Turning Pointe Shelter and its stormwater management system, rain water drained from city streets across the cleared parcel and flowed directly into Goldsborough Creek, carrying sediment and pollutants with it.  After adding construction of the pervious parking area, compost-amended soils and landscaping to the stormwater management system, all water generated onsite is now managed onsite.  Much of the adjacent road runoff is also managed onsite.  Oakland Bay was protected from stormwater pollution generated at Pioneer School by installing a pervious concrete parking lot, permeable paver sidewalks, rain gardens, bioretention swales and compost amended soils and landscaping.   After construction of the LID projects, no stormwater runoff has been generated from either demonstration site.  Furthermore, water draining from adjacent roadways is also being infiltrated into onsite soils rather than draining offsite into Oakland Bay or Goldsborough Creek.  In fact, the stormwater infiltration capacity of the LID features is so effective that it has been impossible to conduct water quality monitoring at the Pioneer School site as originally planned; there was simply not enough ponding water to capture meaningful samples. Performance Items and Deliverables Demonstration Site #1: Turning Pointe •	9,281 sf pervious concrete parking lot•	24,339 sf of compost-amended soils •	6,419 sf of new native landscapingDemonstration Site #2: Pioneer Intermediate/Middle School•	10,898 sf pervious concrete parking lot•	2 bioretention swales totaling 2,663 sf•	2 rain gardens totaling 1802 sf•	Permeable paver sidewalk section•	4,637 sf of compost-amended soils & landscapingThe demonstration projects included interpretive signage, media publicity, community and student workshops, and post-construction site monitoring.   In addition, engineering plans were submitted.

column1: HCSEG will demonstrate under actual homeowner site operation, the nitrogen and fecal coliform removal effectiveness for recirculating gravel filter and woodchip bed systems.   A recently completed Department of Health/ University of Washington research project on OSS nitrogen removal has shown that a low cost 2 stage Recirculating Gravel Filter (RFG) and Woodchip Bed system can reduce nitrogen by greater than 90% and fecal coliform bacteria by greater than 96%.  Homeowner acceptance and the operation and maintenance needs under realistic conditions will be evaluated.  The locations selected will be nearshore lower Hood Canal properties.  HCSEG’s objectives include verifying nitrogen removal effectiveness with reasonable installation, operation, maintenance and inspection costs so that this technology can be adopted watershed wide in the lower Hood Canal and other Puget Sound region watersheds. column2: Purpose:  1)  Remedial activities to correct and control point sources of pollution that threaten shellfish harvest in Totten/Little Skookum Inlets.  Fecal coliform bacteria from agriculture sources (livestock) and failing septic systems is the targeted pollutant.  The project will also evaluate and develop a proposal for longterm funding options to protect shellfish harvesting areas. Results:  Task 1.  Agricultural Remedial Activities.  1)  Update of the 1989 Totten watershed farm inventory.  2)  Adoption of a Memorandum of Understanding between Thurston Conservation District and Thurston county Environmental Health.  3)  Evaluation, update, and implementation of all existing farm plans.  4)  Development and implementation of farm plans for priority farm sites.  5)  Cost-share incentives and crew availability for implementation of farm plans.  6)  Five educational workshops on best management practices (BMPs) were held.  Ten educational articles on BMPs were published. Outreach booths at three community events were established. 7)  A total of 133 BMPs were implemented on farms and $13,973 in cost-share for water quality BMPs was expended. Task 2. column1: The purpose of the project was to collect watershed analysis resource condition indices data for the major salmonid streams in the areas covered by the Totten-Skookum, Eld, and Oakland Bay Watershed Management plans. column2: Sampling methods were in accordance with the Timber Fish and Wildlife Program's Ambient Monitoring Program Manual (included in grant file).  A report was prepared on stream characteristics, riparian shade, pool habitat, large woody debris (LWD), and spawning gravel fine sediment. Many stream segments in the study area are sensitive to temperature increases, and most did not have adequate shade to maintain temperatures within state standards.  Most segments rated poorly for abundance of functional key LWD pieces.  The riparian stands need more conifers to increase shade and to provide large, rot-resistant pieces of LWD. Excessive levels of fine sediment were found in the majority of streams. Forest practices appear to have disturbed stream channels, removed riparian vegetation, and increased erosion.  Watershed analysis prescriptions in sensitive areas can reduce future impacts.  Effects from other land-uses, such as residential development, must be addressed to improve or maintain habitat in the long run. The report recommended developing appropriate prescriptions for forest practices and activities such as residential development to limit runoff and fine sediment input, and to protect riparian vegetation.  Projects should be implemented to educate landowners, restore vegetation, increase LWD abundance, control sediment input, and monitor habitat conditions over time.

They had serious concerns about inlet and outlet structures restricting the passage of salmon.  Therefore, the committee, with approval from the Lake residents, decided to continue with the whole lake Sonar treatment, but to follow-up the treatment with diver inspection, hand-pulling, bottom barrier installation, and/or partial Sonar treatment in the year following the Sonar treatment.  The Plan was amended accordingly. During the summer of 1996, Lake Limerick was treated with Sonar.  Concentrations were initially made up to 20 ppb and declined to half that amount over a two-week period.  Fluridone (Sonar's active ingredient) samples were taken at intervals, and every two weeks, the applicator applied enough Sonar to bring the whole lake concentration back to 20 ppb.  Sonar was applied four times. Initial results seem promising with a fall survey showing about a 90 percent decrease in Brazilian elodea biomass.  Another spring survey is planned, with follow-up treatment being funded with another Aquatic Weeds grant and a SRF loan.

column1: Mason County Conservation District will use this money to improve water quality and restore salmon and wildlife habitat on degraded streams in the Oakland Bay Watershed. column2: The Mason Conservation District completed an inventory of farms in the watershed.  Farms were prioritized on the basis of impact to water quality due to direct access of livestock to surface waters. Of a total of 327 active farms, 53 were ranked high priority.  The inventory database was updated regularly.  Subbasins were also prioritized on the basis of evident degradation, and the potential for restoration to improve salmon production, habitat and water quality.  Landowners were contacted through four separate mailings and follow-up phone calls.  Sixty-three farm plans were completed; thirteen for high priority farms in high priority subbasins.  Twenty-six of 53 priority farms in high priority subbasins implemented a total of 97 BMPs.  A total of approximately 360 BMPs were implemented, far exceeding grant requirements.  The District provided information to all landowners regarding the availability of technical assistance, agricultural land tax incentives, conservation easements, land trusts, and cost share incentives. Four cooperators were given conservation farm signs upon completion of projects and farm plans.  Each year the District gave a "Wildlife Habitat Farm of the Year" award to a landowner that showed exemplary management of his/her farm.  The award recognized landowners for implementing BMPs and managing their farm to allow for minimal impact.  Landowners were given a 20" x 24" sign and were also recognized in the media.  The District offered a Homestead Improvement Program as another incentive to landowners to gain skills necessary to implement BMPs on their own property.  Classes included instruction and hands- on demonstrations of various management practices.  The twenty participants "paid back" for class attendance by volunteering on a labor crew to assist others in the community.  Participants rated this training well, but the District felt the return was low relative to the effort and expense of preparing and advertising for the classes.  The District participated in 51 educational events including fairs and festivals, classes, and farm tours, reaching many children and adults of the watershed - exceeding grant requirements.  The District conducted nine workshops with a total of 172 participants (exceeding grant requirements). column1: The immediate purpose of the project was to eliminate the inadequate Wollochet Harbor treatment plant by intercepting it to an existing larger municipal sewerage system at Gig Harbor.  The water quality goal was to remove the largest source of contamination from the inner waters of Wollochet Harbor, thus removing a significant obstacle to the possible recertification of shellfish harvest areas there.
column2: The Wollochet Harbor treatment plant was eliminated.  All sewage from the Wollochet Harbor Sewer District was intercepted to Gig Harbor, where it now received the legally required degree of treatment.  A significant source of contamination was removed from inner Wollochet Harbor, enabling the State Health Department to consider recertifying shellfish beds there.  The last primary treatment plant in Ecology's Northwest Regional (and possibly in Washington State) was eliminated.  The District completed two components of this project using the Small Towns Environment Program (STEP) method.  The first part was the installation of a new collection system, including 24 septic tank effluent pumps.  The preliminary estimate for this project, assuming the use of an outside contractor was $95,000.  The District used volunteer labor, their consultant (Gray & Osborne) donated an inspector and the District purchased the materials.  The approximate final cost for this portion was $25,000, a savings of $70,000.  The second part of the work accomplished through using STEP was the landscaping.  The District received a bid for the landscaping work of approximately $45,000.  The District chose to perform the work, for the most part, by themselves.  The total cost for the landscaping project, using volunteer labor, the Labor-Ready manpower pool, and materials procurement by the District, was approximately $17,000, a savings of $28,000.

column1: Kitsap County will use the money to assess the current level of citizen awareness about stormwater and nonpoint pollution; educate the citizens about their impact on water quality, and promote behavior changes.  This is a multi-jurisdictional approach to be undertaken by various local, state, and federal agencies located within Kitsap County.
column2: Conducted a baseline survey of citizen's knowledge of stormwater and nonpoint pollution.  400 citizens were interviewed.  Produced a comprehensive report analyzing the results of the baseline survey.  Using results of the survey, developed education adds to present to citizen focus groups.  Organized and conducted citizen focus groups which assisted with refining education material and messages.  Advertised refined education material in local newspapers, stores, businesses and the County Fair. Conducted a follow-up survey of 400 citizens, 100 of who had participated in the baseline survey.   The survey assessed the effectiveness of the project's education program. Produced a report analyzing the findings of the follow-up survey.  Follow-up survey results indicated that: over 50% of respondents recalled seeing, hearing or reading water quality education information generated  through this project.  About one-third of survey respondents claim to have modified their behavior to help reduce nonpoint pollution.  Note:  This project was very successful and managed extremely well by Pat Kirschbaum of Kitsap County Stormwater and Surface Water Management.  All the required reports were well done and very comprehensive. The project was also completed ahead of schedule and required "no" time extensions.

column1: The city of Bremerton will use the money to educate businesses and citizens of Bremerton about stormwater reduction measures and point and nonpoint source pollution prevention practices they can use.
column2: Completed 10 multimedia workshops to educate citizens on CSO reduction.  Developed an internet website for distributing program information.  Developed 2 separate education videos. One described the goals of the program and sewer system operations; the other demonstrates how to separate rain leaders from the sewer system.  Developed and distributed over 22,000 self help brochures describing the CSO reduction program and downspout separation.  Produced a public access television segment on the CSO reduction program.  Developed standard engineering configurations of rain leaders going to storm sewers. Distributed these documents during property site assessments.  Advertised program through mailings, billboards and newspapers.   Simplified right of way permit process to complete CSO improvement work.   Completed 2,848 CSO separation property site assessments.  Completed 44 CSO separations in the right of way and a total of 358 separations during the life of the project.  As a result of the project an estimated 260,000 gallons of stormwater runoff per inch of rain has been removed from the Bremerton sanitary sewer system.

column1: The Kitsap Conservation District will use the money to fund technical assistance to landowners for farm planning, design, and implementation of best management practices (BMPs), BMP monitoring, and water quality education of Burley residents.
column2: The agricultural inventory found that the number of agricultural properties in the watershed had increased from 165 in 1998 to 247 in 2002; the number on agricultural landowners had increased from 94 to 170 during the same period.  Priorities relative to agricultural practices and water quality for many properties have changed, some improved and some degraded relative to the baseline inventory.  The inventory information was incorporated into a mailing list that was used in the outreach effort.  This grant enabled the District to develop 23 farm plans and complete 34 incentive program applications.  Of those applications, 33 incentive grants were awarded through EQUIP and CREP totaling $109,366 to complete projects such as waste storage structures, heavy use area protection, fencing, fish stream improvements, and pasture planting.  District staff developed 54 site specific best management practices designs that conformed with NRCS standards and specifications.  These included (in order of frequency): fencing, heavy use area protection, pasture planting, waste storage structures, waste storage structures, waste storage structure roof, pipeline, roof and runoff management, tree and shrub establishment, diversion, underground outlets, and animal trails and walkways.  Technical and planning services were provided for BMP implementation, including supplies and materials lists, on-site project management to oversee installation, and processing of cost share reimbursement.  A total of 82 BMP implementation projects were completed. WCC crews were used in 10 projects.   Operation and maintenance agreements were signed by landowners at the time cost-share was awarded. District staff inspected completed BMPs regularly for operational problems, effectiveness, and ease of maintenance.  Follow-up assistance was provided to encourage proper maintenance and address any concerns.  Thirteen (13) sites received follow-up BMP monitoring.   In addition, 13 sites were used for BMP demonstration purposes for interested agencies, groups and individuals.  Over the course of the grant, the District responded to complaint referrals from state and local agencies.  These included 12 water quality complaints from Kitsap County Health Department (KCHD) and Department of Ecology, six solid waste complaints from KCHD, four land use referrals and two open space tax program referrals.  In addition to the landowner mailing list mentioned above, the District publicized the project through various methods, including two newspaper articles, 11 District newsletters and 15 public events.  The District conducted a total of 28 educational presentations or programs, including: waste management workshops, farm management slide show presentations and workshops, farm tours, habitat for life workshops, wetlands and wildlife class, woodland management class.

column1: The Health Services will use the money to focus on the shellfish growing areas in Lower Hood Canal with the primary intent to identify the nonpoint pollution sources of fecal contamination bacteria along the waterfront area from Gladwin Road to Cherokee Beach on the North Shore of the Canal.
column2: Identified the non-point sources of fecal contamination along the waterfront area from Gladwin Beach Road to Boad Havan Road.  Helped identify a number of possible solutions for the impacted community. Confirmed contamination originating from Belfair State Park, leading to elimination of a major source.  Proved that untreated effluent could move underground and surface out in the marine water, resulting in: - the County Commissioners passing an ordinance placing a moratorium on septic permits in the study area until the study was completed; - Mason County Water Quality Policies and Procedures being amended to provide for better testing methods to identify non-point sources of pollution; - the Belfair Urban Growth area sewerage plan being expanded to include the study area.  Increased awareness and understand of the community.  An improved understanding of the impact shoreline development has on water quality that has been used to improve development practices in other areas of Mason County.

column1: The purpose of this project is to assess all available habitat inventory data (historic and new) on the lower 46 miles of the Columbia River and identify critical wetland habitat functions in need of protection, enhancement, and/or restoration.
column2: Wetland Habitat Assessment - evaluation were completed of existing information about wetland habitat in the Columbia River Estuary to identify critical wetlands. Critical Wetland Habitat Protection and Maintenance - Eight workgroups were charged with responding to a criteria paper developed by estuarine scientists from National Marine Fisheries Service.  An important step was made toward implementing a comprehensive, coordinated, ecosystem-based program for wetland habitat restoration in the lower Columbia River and estuary.  The combination of on the ground investigations of restoration sites which provided a profile of the diversity and extent of restoration opportunities and the enhanced coordination with existing restoration programs provides the programmatic basis for a consensus-based ecosystem restoration strategy.  The infrastructure built for this program is helping leverage additional funds from ongoing authorities that will benefit future restoration planning and implementation or the region.

column1: Liberty Bay is an important national estuary used by threatened salmon, highly regarded species, unique plant communities and estuarine habitats.  The Lemolo Citizens Club will use the money to control nonpoint pollution in Liberty Bay.  Nonpoint pollution in the bay is, at least in part, the result of inadequate buffers, uncontrolled stormwater runoff, and decreasing vegetation with disruption of the natural landscape.  This control program will mitigate these adverse effects and protect salmon habitat with abundant vegetation using native plants while monitoring water quality and gauging results of strategic ongoing remediation activities. The objective of this project is to affect nonpoint source pollution problems through evaluation of existing conditions, implementing strategic fundamental improvements; while promoting citizen stewardship and community-wide public education.  To achieve these goals, the Lemolo Citizens Club will provide volunteer training, shoreline monitoring, nearshore habitat enhancement, and project-based learning opportunities through a highly visible program with strong community support.  A web page will be used to disseminate information and end products will include photographic documentation and development of teaching tools.  School districts will be involved involved through a citizen advisory committee, field trips concurrent with watershed education curricula of elementary aged children and volunteer efforts of junior high and high school students.  The high level of participants committing to this project, willing to lend their expertise, resources and time will ensure project goals are met.
column2: The recipient evaluated physical habitat characteristics, monitored physio-chemical water quality, completed inventory of priority species, developed a program for regular monitoring, and conducted biological sampling. This information will provide a baseline for assessment of ecological conditions in Liberty Bay to support adaptive management, future conservation, enhancement, and restoration efforts.  The recipient provided education for homeowners about erosion and the negative impacts of bulkheads, stormwater, and improper septic system operation and maintenance.  Children and adults had opportunities and places to develop a sense of caring and ownership for marine resources, and to learn how impacts to the nearshore, intertidal, and estuarine habitats are compensated by effective improvements.  By working cooperatively with stakeholders, the recipient mitigated a adverse effects of shoreline development on habitat by planting abundant native vegetation in the nearshore zone.  Volunteer opportunities were easy and fun, and for more complex projects, well supported by advisors. A technical advisory team helped manage activities, shared understanding of the issues, engaged new players, and helped build opportunities for volunteers to participate in monitoring and restoring marine habitats.  Other elements, such as characterizing diversity and abundance of fish species, salt marsh vegetation, benthic and shellfish surveys, provide a gauge of ecosystem functions with which to predict environmental outcomes of future "salmon focused" restoration projects.

column1: KITSAP COUNTY WILL USE THE MONEY TO CONDUCT A POLLUTION IDENTIFICATION AND CORRECTION PROJECT, WHICH TARGETS UNSEWERED KITSP LAKE SHORELINE HOMES AND FECAL COLIFORM ALONG CHICO BAY, AND TO DEVELOP AN "ALTERNATIVE FUTURES" WATERSHED ACTION PLAN WHICH WILL ASSESS HYDROLIC MODELING, GROUNDWATE RMODELING, FISH INVENTORY AND HABITAT, LAND COVER, AND RUNOFF REGIMES BASED SCENARIOS.
column2: CONVENED AND TRAINED A TECHNICAL WORKING GROUP (TWG) WHICH PREPARED RESOURCE ASSESSMENTS FOR THE WATERSHED, AND DEVELOPED ANALYTIC TOOLS FOR THE ALTERNATIVE FUTURES ANALYSIS.  CONVENED AND TRAINED A WATERSHED ADVISORY COMMITTEE (WAC) WHICH CONSISTED OF A GROUP OF WATERSHED RESIDENTS AND STAKEHOLDERS.  KITSAP COUNTY WORKED WITH THE WAC AND CREATED THREE ALTERNATIVE FUTURES SCENARIOS (DEVELOPED, CONSERVATION, AND MODERATE) THAT WOULD DEPICT WHAT THE LANDSCAPE OF A WATERSHED MIGHT LOOK LIKE IN THE FUTURE.  USING THE TOOLS DEVELOPED BY THE TWAG, THE WAC ANALYZED EACH OF THE THREE ALTERNATIVE FUTURES SCENARIOS AND THE PLANNED TREND SCENARIA (I.E., IF NO CHANGE WERE TO OCCUER) FOR THEIR EFFECT ON WATER QUALITY, WATER QUANTITY AND FISH AND WILDLIFE HABITAT, INFRASTRUCTURE COSTS, AND THE POTENTIAL BENEFITS AND IMPACTS OF THE FUTURE LAND USE SCENARIOS.  CREATED AND ADOPTED A WATERSHED PLAN BASED ON NATURAL RESOURCE PROTECTION AND WATERSHED INTEGRITY WHICH WAS DESIGNED AROUND A VISION OF THE FUTURE THAT HAD BEEN ARTICULATED BY THE CITIZENS OF THE WATERSHED, AND IDENTIFY OPPORTUNITIES FOR CONSERVATION AND RESTORATION IN THE WATERSHED, AND PROVIDE FOR MONITORING AND ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT OF WATERSHED RESOURCES.  CHICO WATERSHED INTERPRETIVE SIGNS & INFORMATION KIOSKS-SIGNS WERE DEVELOPED AND INSTALLED AT VARIOUS LOCATIONS AROUND THE WATERSHED TO INFORM WATERSHED RESIDENTS AND VISITORS ABOUT THE PROJECT AND OPPORTUNITIES FOR PARTICIPATION AND PROVIDE AN INTRODUCTION TO WATERSHED CONDITIONS AND FACTORS AFFECTING ITS HEALTH.  A PROJECT LOGO WAS DEVELOPED.  CHICO MEDIA INFORMATION, OPINION-EDITORIAL ARTICLES FOR LOCAL NEWSPAPERS-A MEDIA CAMPAIGN WAS IMPLEMENTED TO INCREASE AWARENESS OF THE OVERALL PROJECT, INFORM RESIDENTS ABOUT WATERSHED PROCESSES AND CURRENT CONDITIONS IN THE CHICO WATERSHED AND PROMOTE OPPORTUNITIES FOR CITIZEN INVOLVEMENT IN STEWARDSHIP ACTIVITIES AND WATERSHED PLANNING.  CHICO WATERSHED WEB SITE, FACT SHEETS-CURRENT INFORMATION ABOUT CHICO CREEK PROJECT AND WATERSHED PLANNING EFFORTS WAS OFFERED AT KITSAP COUNTY NATURAL RESOURCES WEB PAGE.  FACT SHEETS WERE PRODUCED AND DISTRIBUTED AT EVENTS TO INFORM PEOPLE ABOUT IMPORTANT WATERSHED PROCESSES, FUNCITONS, AND ISSUES.  CHICO WATERSHED WORKSHOPS - PUBLIC WORKSHOPS AND OPEN HOUSES WERE OFFERED ON A VARIETY OF TOPICS INCLUDING NATURAL LAWN CARE, PASTURE AND FARM MANAGEMENT AND GROUND WATER, WELL MAINTENANCE, MANAGEMENT OF SMALL WOODED PROPERTIES, OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE OF ON-SITE SEWAGE DISPOSAL SYSTEMS, AND SALMON FRIENDLY HOME AND GARDEN PRACTICES.  COMMUNITY PRESENTATIONS & COMMUNITY LEADER RECRUITMENT - PRESENTATIONS WERE MADE TO APPOINTED AND ELECTED OFFICIALS AND COMMUNITY LEADERS AND MEMBERS THAT ILLUSTRATE THE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN LAND USE AND WATERSHED CONDITIONS (E.G., BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES (BMPS) FOR MITIGATING OR MINIMIZING IMPACTS OF VARIOUS LAND USES.  CHICO WATERSHED TOUR-GUIDED AND SEL-GUIDED TOURS WERE DEVELOPED TO PROVIDE AN OPPORTUNITY TO LEARN ABOUT WATERSHED FUNCTIONS IN GENERAL AND SPECIFIC INFORMATION ABOUT THE CHICO WATERSHED.  WATERSHED ACADEMY - ALL POTENTIAL VOLUNTEERS FOR THE WATERSHED ADVISORY COMMITTEE WERE REQUIRED TO COMPLETE AN EDUCATIONAL COURSE ABOUT WATERSHED AND PLANTING PROCESSES CALLED "THE WATERSHED ACADEMY".  THIS WAS THE MAJOR EDUCATIONAL EFFORT IN THE PROCESS.  THIS 27-HOUR CURRICULUM GAVE THE COMMITTEE AN INFORMED BACKGROUND FROM WHICH TO BEGIN THE PLANNING PROCESS.  WATER QUALITY MONITORING AND POLLUTION IDENTIFICATION AND CORRECTION (KITSAP COUNTY HEALTH DISTRICT) - ONE HUNDRED THIRTEEN (113) WERE SELECTED FOR PROPERTY SURVEYS FOR THE PURPOSE OF COLLECTING HOMEOWNER INFORMATION AND TO IDENTIFY ALL POTENTIAL SOURCES OF FECAL COLIFORM CONTAMINATION.  THESE INCLUDED 75 LAKE SHORELINE AND 17 UPLAND PROPERTIES IN THE KITSAP LAKE AREA, AND 10 MARINE SHORELINE AND 11 UPLAND PROPERTIES IN THE CHICO BAY AREA.  SHORELINE SURVEYS AND WATER QUALITY MONITORING WERE ALSO CONDUCTED.  MONTHLY MONITORING OCCURRED AT FOUR STREAM LOCATIONS AND BI-MONTHLY MONITORING AT ONE MARINE LOCATION; IN ADDITION, IMPACT MONITORING WAS CONDUCTED IN CONNECTION WITH THE IDENTIFICATION OF SPECIFIC SOURCES OF FECAL COLIFORM POLLUTION.  OF THE 113 PROPERITES, 104 (92 PERCENT) WERE SURVEYED, ONE WAS VACANT, AND SIX EITHER DID NOT PARTICIPATE OR DENIED ACCESS FOR INSPECITON.  OF THE 104; 14 ON-SITE SEPTIC SYSTEM FAILURES (13) PERCENT WERE FOUND; 3 SUSPECT ON-SITE SEPTICE SYSTEM FAILURES (3 PERCENT) WERE FOUND, 26 NONCONFORMING ON-SITE SEPTIC SYSTEMS (25 PERCENT) WERE FOUND; 28 ON-SITE SEPTIC SYSTEMS (27 PERCENT) WITH NO RECORDS WERE FOUND; AND 33 ON-SITE SEPTIC SYSTEMS (32 PERCENT) HAD NO APPARANT PROBLEMS.  OF THE REMAINING SIX PROPERTIES, ONE CONNECTED TO SEWER, SURFACE WATER SAMPLING SHOWED THAT FOUR HAD NO CONTRIBUTION TO FECAL COLIFORM LEVELS IN SURFACE WATERS, AND ONE REMAINS UNDER INVESTIGATION.  ONE URBAN WILDLIFE SOURCE WAS FOUND AND ADDRESSED.

column1: The Mason Conservation District will use the money to identify sources of fecal coliform bacteria and other contaminants in the lower Union River and its estuary.  Remediation measures will be developed and implemented, which will include a plan for the control and treament of stormwter in the Belfair urban growth areas.
column2: Mason County Department of Health Services developed a parcel ranking system, researching parcel files in an effort to identify which on-site wastewater systems were most likely to be failing or contributing to fecal coliform contamination.  Mason Conservation District conducted an agricultural inventory of landowners and properties ranked for their potential to contribute to non-point source pollution to the lower Union River watershed.  They also developed farm plans with associated Best Management Practices and restoration practices for participating landowners.Hood Canal Salmon Enhancement Group led trained volunteers in a water and sediment sampling effort effort throughout the lower Union River, its tributaries, and the Lynch Cove estuary.  Water samples were collected monthly from 25 stations over the course of one year.  The goal of the sampling effort was to identify sources of fecal coliform pollution and to investigate the potential source of toxic contaminants.  Mason County Department of Health Services (MCDHS) followed up at "high-risk" sites (utilizing ranked parcel information and water quality data) to assist in the location and remediation of fecal coliform sources.  MCDHS conducted sanitary surveys and dye testing, when necessary, of on-site wastewater systems with cooperating landowners.  Five hundred and fifty seven properties were evaluated as high, medium or low potential for bacterial pollution to the Union River and its tributaries.As part of the study, over 500 parcels were examined via map and database and ranked for their potential to contribute fecal coliform contamination.  The ranking was based on septic system age, type, and location to waterways.  Sanitary surveys were performed on the parcels most at-risk to contribute fecal coliform.  A conceptual stormwater control plan was completed in an effort to eliminate the Belfair Urban Growth Area as a source of pollution to Lynch Cove and Hood Canal.  The Lower Union River Stormwater Study was completed by Engineering Services Associates in May 2006.  Three community outreach workshops and two stewardship programs were held to engage local citizens and inform them of the current pollution issues in Union River, including updates of the water sampling effort, septic system care and maintenance, status of the Operation and Maintenance Program in the area, proper livestock waste management, and overall farm best management practices.  These workshops included stewardship information and other educational materials provided by each of the participating organizations.

column1: Kitsap County will use the money to create a watershed and community plan for the Barker Creek Watershed using a technique called, "Alternative Futures Planning". This technique provides analysis of various water resource management scenarios.  Each series of scenarios will be evaluated for its effect on water quality, water quantity, and fish and wildlife habitat.
column2: The Barker Watershed and Windy Point Shoreline Pollution Identification and Correction Project led by the Kitsap County Health District and with the KCD.  The Health District monitored FC levels from Island Lake, Barker Creek , and other fresh water drainages from Barker Creek and the Windy Point Shorelines.  Fifteen (15) sources were identified, including 9 failing on-site systems, one inadequate trailer dump station, 1 pet waste violation, and 4 livestock handling problems.  All but three requiring further investigation were corrected. The Health District conducted an intensive public education campaign including three public meetings regarding best management practices for on-sites, pet waste, stormwater, pond operation, and farming.  Barker Creek continues to have a closure zone established around it due to exceedances of state primary contact standard for FC and Windy Point remains classified as "Conditionally Approved".   Overall, the water quality monitoring did not find a lot of FC sources in this drainage nor any that were directly impacting the stream.   However, the trend monitoring found FC levels are coming down.  Kitsap Conservation District led the Barker Watershed Agricultural Limiting Factors Correction Program to improve poor agricultural practices as potential watershed nonpoint pollution.  Under this program eight farm management plans were written and twenty agricultural best management practices installed including exclusion fencing, and riparian planting.  Six newsletters, eight technical assistance mailings, seventeen public event activities, and thirteen presentations/educational programs were conducted.  Kitsap County Development of Community Development (DCD) led the Barker Watershed Alternative Futures Planning project intended to have land use decision makers understand and protect beneficial watershed uses.  Watershed characterization included a groundwater-surface water model on GIS, measurement of channel complexity, a Hydrologic Simulation Program - Fortran (HSPF) watershed model using precipitation, stream flow, groundwater level and lake level data conducted by the Army Corps of Engineers, GIS land use maps including land cover, sewers, roads, critical areas, wildlife. Two open houses, 6-evening Watershed Academy, and workshops for area residents were conducted.  The Alternatives Futures planning process identified realistic future land use under "expansive", "moderate", and "plan trend" scenarios showing levels of imperviousness and forest cover in a "virtual build out".  The Corps of Engineers created a HSPF stream flow model that showed the more urbanized model had more flashy conditions, a modeled greater stream flow to have better fish habitat.  A Riverine Habitat Simulation (RHABSIM) modeled salmon habitat for each HSPF scenario.  During the time of the grant the Barker Creek watershed sub-area plan became part of the Kitsap County Comprehensive Plan. column2: Kitsap County Health Distric conducted fecal coliform source identification (shoreline surveys) along Kitsap County's developed shoreline during dry and wet seasons.  Eighty-six properties were surveyed which consisted of on-site septic systems (OSS) record search, homeowner/resident interview, field inspection, and water samples and dye test when necessary.  Kitsap Health identified and investigated fecal coliform hotspots and conducted property surveys and investigations in these areas.  County staff provided owners and residents with site-specific suggestions to avoid premature OSS failures, how to keep bacteria and nutrients out of Hood Canal, and enforced correction of failing OSS pursuant to state and local OSS regulations.  Kitsap health presented project methods and results for public and peer workshops.  A subset of Hood Canal shoreline discharges was sampled to continue correlation study of fecal coliform (FC) and nearby control drainages before and after OSS correction to determine FC and nutrient reductions.  This pilot nutrient study was limited to seven cities that were suitable for the investigation based on the ability to estimate or measure flow and whether the failure was found during the spring when groundwater flows are highest.  Kitsap County's upper Hood Canal shoreline does not have a serious OSS failure problem based on project results.  This is supported by Kitsap Health's trend monitoring data for the water year, Sept. 2008.  Nine of the eleven marine water monitoring stations in the project area meet both parts of Washington State's water quality standard for FC.  Thirty-one FC pollution sources related to failing OSS were identified and were either corrected of vacated.  The Lofall area has a serious FC pollution problem which is currently being addressed in the Jump Off Joe PIC project.  Though preliminary pilot nutrient study results show no correlation between FC and nitrate+nitrite nitrogen in shoreline discharges sampled for this project it was found that failing OSS do contribute nitrogen and further investigation is needed.  Pre- and post-FC Source Correction (BACI) results showed statistically significant nutrient reductions at the 95% confidence level after OSS correction compared to controls.

column1: The money will be used to conduct shoreline septic system surveys for the properties bordering the Hood Canal and to complete enhancements to the on-site septic system database.
column2: OSS surveys were conducted between August 2005 and August 2008.  Since July 2005, the County has surveyed 44.4 miles along Hood Canal for shoreline discharges.  Spanning a period of 107 days, over 1,800 water samples have been collected and analyzed for FC from 1,416 individual shoreline sites.  Based on results, the property distance from surface water is the most common factor contributing to identification of on-site septic system (OSS) failure, followed by age of system and previous repairs. Seventy-five of the systems identified as failures were traditional gravity systems.  The County identified close to 2,090 parcels that were developed within 1000 feet of Hood Canal.  29 properties of interest were identified from 27 monitoring locations.  An additional property was identified on the north shore of Hood Canal that occupies a shellfish closure zone.  Sanitary surveys were performed at 17 of the 29 identified properties.  Twelve of the properties were not surveyed either because the property owners did not respond to County requests or the County was unable to contact the owner within the time allotted.  Five of the properties were identified at the end of the project, leaving little time to attempt contact of the residents.  Of the eight properties with identified OSS failures, six were less than twenty feet from surface water, with most of those systems located directly behind the bulkhead.  All eight properties have excessive storm, surface, or ground water that most likely contributed to the onsite system failure.  Five of the failing OSS are repaired, one is at design phase, and one owner has yet to be notified due to the potential intersection of a storm drain with the drainfield.  One failure was visually identified as having a direct discharge out of bulkhead drains.  The County conducted fourteen public meetings, workshops, and water quality-related events to inform homeowners in the Hood Canal region about the project.  Presentations included information on the practices homeowners can implement to reduce fecal coliform and nutrient pollution.  Following are methodologies used and observations obtained throughout the project:  Properties adjacent to and not more than 1000 feet from the shoreline were prioritized for surveys and investigations.  When shoreline discharges were observed, samples of water were collected and tested according to procedures set forth in the project Quality Assurance Project Plan (QAPP) and Standar Operating Procedures (SOP).  High FC sample results triggered additional confirmation sampling. The combination of the property address, site description, GPS coordinates, and photos allowed staff to reliably identify the sites for confirmation sampling.  During the project, staff found that samples with high salinity readings had typically low levels of FC; therefore samples were no longer collected at sites with salinity readings above 20 ppt.  Sanitary surveys included a parcel file onsite septic system (OSS) record review, a Carmody Operation & Maintenance database search, and an interview with the homeowner or resident. The property was surveyed to identify the location of OSS components and their condition.  Staff inspected for obvious signs of failure such as surfacing sewage or sewage odors.  Additionally, septic systems were inspected for signs of poor system location or physical damage such as gutter downspouts directed toward system components, or cracked tank lids.  Dye tests were performed when indicated (with permission of the system owner) to identify any outbreaks from the system, incomplete treatment, or grey water discharges.  The sanitary survey provided the opportunity to educate the resident about the proper operation and maintenance of a septic system in order to prolong system life and ways to protect it from unintentional damage.  Non-OSS sources were addressed by recommending owner implement best management practices such as picking up pet waste, composting of yard waste, and surface water runoff management.

City will also conduct outreach to the following groups to coordinate educational opportunities and information: North Kitsap School District, Kitsap Home Builders Association, Poulsbo Marine Science Center, and Liberty Foundation. Two bioretention swalestotalling approximately 800 feet will be constructed to infiltrate and retain runoff. A bioretention cell will also be constructed in a traffic island. Design will be consistent with the Puget Sound Action Team's LIDTechnical Guidance Manual for Puget Sound (2005). Treated stormwater will be directed to the City-owned collection system and then through existing City-owned detention facilities prior to discharge to South Fork DogfishCreek. On-sit conists of a sign at the intersection identifying the LID project, and interpretive panel display adjacent to the bioretention swale andporous concrete sidewalk. Off-site consists of a poster in the lobby of the Engineering and pLanning BUilding and Public Work Building, describing LID techniques, as well as the City's regulatory framework for LID.Brochure will be developed for handout to citizens and developers, copies made available at the Development Counter and on RECIPIENT's Web site. Project monitoring will be performed in accordance with a QAPP and Monitoring plan. Qualitative monitoring consists of photographs of porous and non-porous concrete, and bioretention swalesconventional bilfiltration swale performance during representative rain events. Quantitative monitoring will include water quality monitoring of inflow and outflow, for both bioretention facilities and conventionalbiofiltration swales that are located immediately adjacent to the site. Qualitative flow monitoring will also be conducted to estimate effectiveness of porous concrete and bioretention facilities.

column1: The Kitsap County Health District (KCHD) will use the money to inform area citizens of water quality problems and pollution identification and correction activities in the Jump-Off-Joe Creek watershed.  The KCHD will also survey on-site septic systems for fecal coliform sources in the Jump-off-Joe Creek watershed, and the adjacent Hood Canal shoreline.  The KCHD will correct the identified sources through a combination of public education and enforcement of local on-site sewage and solid waste regulations.  Through this project, the KCHD will determine if fecal coliform pollution sources like failing onsite sewage systems and animal waste are significant sources of nutrient pollution to Jump-Off-Joe Creek and Hood Canal receiving waters, and whether they are reduced after fecal coliform source correction.
column2: Water Quality and Environmental Outcomes KCHD Pollution Identification and Correction (PIC) work in 2008 and 2009 resulted in decreasing FC concentrations in Jump off Joe Creek. FC concentrations at the mouth of Jump off Joe Creek met regulatory standards by June 15, 2009. Consequently, DOH removed the shellfish closure zone at the mouth of Jump off Joe Creek in October 2009. Performance Items and Deliverables In total PIC surveys were performed at 412 properties in the Vinland, Jump off Joe, Lofall and Kinman Creek watersheds and the shoreline was surveyed from NBK-Bangor to Driftwood Keys. Twenty-eight OSS failures were discovered and repaired during the project.  Factors that contributed to the failures were similar to those found in other KCHD PIC projects. OSS age, soil type, water table elevation, proximity to surface waters, physical damage to drainfields and hydraulic overloading of the system by residents contributed to many of the failures found during the project. Additionally seven failing OSS discharging to the beach were discovered and repaired/replaced. Pets, wildlife, and stormwater runoff were also informally observed to be contributors to watershed FC loading. Water quality awareness was raised by educating residential owners/occupants on how to prevent FC pollution. Outreach techniques included public meetings, press releases and door to door parcel surveys, sharing information about how to prevent bacterial and nutrient contamination of Jump Off Joe Creek and Hood Canal.Additional Comments: Provide any other discussion about performance, outcomes, etc., including items that could not be accomplished, that are of note that occurred during the project.During the course of the project FC bacteria concentrations initially decreased in Jump off Joe, Vinland and Kinman Creeks.  By the end of the project, the trend was stationary in Jump off Joe and Vinland Creeks. Water quality in Lofall Creek initially worsened and then improved dramatically in 2011. Shoreline sampling proved a useful tool for locating FC sources along the Hood Canal Shoreline. Nutrient data was collected with little correlation found to project activities.

column1: The Silverdale Community Campus LID Retrofit and Development project offers a unique opportunity to build innovative stormwater technologies into the design for a new community campus in a high-density urban development setting. This highly visible project will retrofit and redevelop a 12-acre community site using an array of low impact development (LID) techniques such as pervious pavement, bio-retention cells, and vegetated filter strips. These LID features will be engineered to treat existing and new stormwater being discharge via a piped perennial creek directly to Dyes Inlet Estuary shellfish beds. The project also includes post-installation monitoring and public outreach elements to educate watershed residents, developers, and commercial property owners about the ecological benefits and decreased maintenance consists of LID stormwater management approaches.
column2: Water Quality and Environmental Outcomes The following improvements are anticipated as a result of this project: minimum ninety percent (90%) containment and 100% treatment of stormwater from the site.Performance Items and Deliverables The following improvements have been realized as a result of this project:Remove 45,000 square feet of asphalt parking surface, install 75,600 square feet of new pervious pavement, install 35,000 square feet of bioretention swales (to treat runoff), and install 50,000 square feet of native drought tolerant vegetation. Additionally a pre-design report, final construction documents, and a site maintenance plan were completed. Two neighborhood meetings were held.Additional Comments: Provide any other discussion about performance, outcomes, etc., including items that could not be accomplished, that are of note that occurred during the project.This project was slow to take shape early on but came into sharp focus once Kitsap County assumed grant management oversight. Despite getting a very late start, all grant-funded elements were completed on time.Two specific challenges were encountered during the grant project:1.	This site is adjacent to, and included design features that would affect and other Ecology-grant funded effort. However, water quality benefits associated with this newer project will support and improve upon the earlier installation. As a result, this part of the project was deemed a worthy investment.2.	The contractor accidentally installed pervious pavement over ATB (which had been installed to allow construction truck access to the YMCA building). This is not a typical LID installation. However, based on an analysis performed by the engineering consultant, and with the County’s commitment to monitor the site’s performance, Ecology allowed the installation to proceed.

column2: Results:  This project was only partially successful in that it identified a number of sources of bacterial contamination, implemented the correction of some of them, and began implementation of some others.  However, it did not bring about an improvement in marine water quality significant enough to maintain the shellfish harvest classification of all of Rocky Bay.  On August 11, 1995, the Washington State Department of Health did downgrade a portion of Rocky Bay, prohibiting commercial shellfish harvest in the affected portion. The study found no continuous major sources of bacterial contamination to Rocky Bay.  This finding demonstrates that the shallow, narrow inner portion of Rocky Bay is extremely sensitive to bacterial contamination, whatever the source.  The inner bay's high sensitivity to low level bacterial contamination may indicate that even the small or intermittent fc contributions, in addition to the background fc concentrations, may be enough to tip the balance from acceptable to unacceptable.  The bright side of this conclusion is that remediation of contaminant sources may be limited to correction of a modest number of small problem areas rather than many larger problem areas. Among the positive outcomes of this project is that Rocky Bay and the watershed are better known and understood, paving the way for a more focused, rapid response to the downgrade that occurred late in the course of the project. During the duration of this grant, a broad-based Closure Response Committee met and formulated a remedial action plan to prevent further water quality deterioration and to restore water quality to the extent that the prohibited area can again be classified as open for commercial shellfish harvest.  The grant project contributed to the known information about Rocky Bay and its watershed. The report makes several recommendations for further sampling, education, and protective land use standards, as follows: - Additional freshwater sampling is needed to better define the sources of bacteria found in some shoreline drains (such as stations 8, 9, and 10), and to evaluate corrections implemented to date. - Further marine water sampling, concurrent with freshwater sampling should be conducted under moderate to heavy rainfall conditions to update existing information on the relationship of marine water quality to freshwater inputs.  Marine water sampling should include sample collection under both ebb and flood tide conditions. - The sanitary survey of shoreline homes, especially adjacent to the prohibited area, should be repeated using a more sensitive method, such as charcoal packets. - TPCHD should establish a regular septic system operation and maintenance schedule for all systems in the watershed, including review of all system components and education of system owners. - An on-going funding source for all watershed monitoring activities needs to be developed.  Funding for on-going agricultural outreach and implementation of BMPs should be included. - Protective land use standards are needed to prevent water quality degradation from watershed development. - Other potential sources of bacterial loading to Rocky Bay, such as wildlife, household pets, bacterial growth in sediments or presence of nonfecal species such as Klebsiella should be evaluated.

column2: Purpose:  To restore good water quality in Dyes Inlet watershed.  Due to water quality problems associated tih failing on-site sewage systems (OSS), the Bremerton-Kitsap County Health Distrist will conduct an intensive OSS sanitary survey of the Rocky Point/Marine Drive area between December 93 and March 95 to identify and correct failing OSS ad to determine, if possible, the area's long-term suitability for treating and disposing sewage through individual OSS.  The project will carry out three tasks:  preoproject marine water quality monitoring, a shoreline survey, and an OSS sanitary survey. Results:  1)  Produced Rocky Point/Marine Drive Area On-Site Sewage Systems Sanitary Survey Project, April 1995.  2)  The sanitary survey was conducted an 331 OSS.  42 were identified as failing. By 1996 these failing OSS were corrected (repaired/replaced) pursuant to local regulations.  3)  Pre and post-corrective marine water quality was performed.  Post-corrective monitoring proved inconclusive, but did find a "flip-flop" with greater coliform numbers found during the dry season and lesser fecal coliform numbers found in the wet season.  The Health District determined that these inconclusive numbers resulted from a poor monitoring plan design relying on too few monitoring events. 4)  A long-term OSS suitability summary of the area recommended OSS repair/replacement, connection to a community OSS, or conclusion to a municipal sewerage system as possible solutions.

column1: PUD #1 of Kitsap County has two wells and is currently constructing a production well in the Seabeck Aquifer.  It is believed that numerous small system and domestic wells also tap into this relatively shallow aquifer.  The geologic unit is situated at a depth which varies between 20 and 400 feet below land surface and consists of Vashon-age glacial outwash.  The degree and manner of surface development and activities over the recharge area which feeds the aquifer is of extreme concern to the PUD.  The principal goals of this project are to:  Evaluate the recharge area of the aquifer; Evaluate the potential impacts of surface development and activity on the quantity and quality of water in the aquifer; and Develop methods and protocols to effectively protect, monitor, and manage the surface and gound water systems.
column2: The project accomplished the following results:  Formed Project Review Committee with representation from Kitsap County, local water purveyors, businesses, and citizens to have input into project and draft Aquifer Protection Plan; Set up series of monitoring well network to determine water levels and water quality; Collected ground water data, developed a computerized database of the available hydrogeologic and land-use data for the Seabeck Aquifer area.  Analyzed data and set up an analytical computer-based ground water model to define Aquifer Protection Plan; Created "Seabeck Aquifer Protection Plan Public Utility District #1 of Kitsap County April 1996" which included the following:  1) a hydrogeologic report which documents the geologic assessment of the Seabeck Aquifer, 2) information on how potential sources of contamination will be monitored, 3) best management practices for potential point and nonpoint pollution, 4) notification processes and emergency response plans in case a problem is identified, and 5) possible actions to take to educate water users on why and how to protect the aquifer.

column1: Establishment of a septic system failure database.  There are five tasks associated with this grant: 1. The database allows staff to track field inspection results of dye tests and other observations by specific property.  A survey form is completed when staff inspects repaired on-site systems.  The District has completed reports based on failures noted with varying soil types, failure causes, age or systems and maintenance.  Information on failures has been fed into the county geographic information system and a county wide map of failures was produced. The District feels that this project can serve as a model for other departments making the transition to electronic aids.  The District feels confident that the system they set up will be able to meet their needs for some time to come. column1: The original objective of this project included: 1. Do education and outreach on boat waste issues; 2. Develop a boat waste ordinance, adopt ordinance, and implement ordinance; 3. Conduct monitoring to evaluate the effectiveness of ordinance implementation activities.
column2: The project reults are as follows: 1. The Health District and Washington Sea Grant (WSG) (under contract to the Health District) conducted education and outreach about the proposed Boat Waste Control Program (BWCP).  Some - The Health District presented the BWCP at the Watersheds '94 Expo in Bellevue. - To marinas, WSG sent out a needs assessment, introduced the BWCP program, and solicited support for an informal advisory committee. - To individual boaters, WSG conducted a survey on boater education interest, and conducted workshops on Exterior slip-slide maintenance, interior slip-slide maintenance, environmental regulations and boating and winterizing your boat.  - The Health District developed and distributed signs to marinas reading: "Please No Discharge of Waste in Marina, Use Pumpouts and Shoreside Facilities" and "No Discharge."  - WSG designed and conducted classes on a Sound Boater Stewardship Program for boaters.  2. Developed "Marine Sewage Control Regulations" ordinance.  This ordinance originally included requirements for installation of sewage control facilities (pumpouts, dump stations and rest rooms), a Health District inspection program, adoption of US Coast Guard marine sanitation device requirements, requirements that floating structures be required to have plumbed sewer lines, and a requirement for marina signage regarding the location and use of sewage control facilities.  The ordinance went through legal review and was presented to the Bremerton-Kitsap County Board of Health for support.  3. In 1997, Sound Options Group, L.L.C., a contractor, was hired to facilitate community input on the new regulation through meetings and work sessions.  4. In May, 1998, the ordinance went before the Board of Health for adoption.  The Board in general supported the ordinance, but did not support installation of sewage facilities or a Health District inspection program.  5. Health District staff continues to work on the regulation based on input from the Board and the regulated community.  It has been seeking consistency; in particular with US Coast Guard law regarding the discharge of untreated sewage from vessels.  The ordinance has been revised to delete the inspection program and the requirement for sewage facilities; these facilities will only be required for new marinas or those undergoing expansion.  The Ordinance is again scheduled to go before the Board this month.  6. Because the Ordinance was not adopted during the grant project period, it was decided that the monitoring task in the grant would be deleted.  The monitoring had been designed to measure water quality improvement with Ordinance implementation.

column2: A plan was developed using a public process and this plan was approved at a public meeting.  The plan has not yet been implemented because of lack of funding. column1: Seattle's project will identify best management practices for stormwater.  The cost and water quality benefits of retrofitting existing stormwater facilities throughout the City will be evaluated.  This will enable Seattle to select the best locations and technologies for future water qualit investments.
column2: Twenty storms were monitored at the Downstream Defender and Vortechs BMP sites and eight storms were monitored at the Stormceptor site, where the installation occurred later in the project. Antecedent conditions, storm intensity, and storm flow rates relative to treatment system design flows are among the variety of factors that influence the performance of any stormwater treatment system and contribute to the statistical variation in pollutant removal rates.  To reduce or at least quantify the uncertainty associated with the performance of each treatment technology, the project used two sampling approaches: the event mean concentration (EMC) method and the discrete flow composite (DFC) sample method.  The results were as follows.  None of the BMPs tested performed well in removing TSS, metals, or nutrients.  Removal rates for most pollutants were frequently less than zero for the Downstream Defender and Vortechs units.  Although the Stormceptor unit achieved overall positive removals for most pollutants (TSS, total copper and zinc, total phosphorus, and soluble reactive phosphorus), removal efficiencies were relatively low (less than 15 percent).  None of the three BMPs met the Washington State Department of Ecology standard (Ecology, 2002) for basic stormwater treatment devices (80 percent TSS removal). Low removal rates for TSS may be caused by several factors, including (1) low TSS concentrations in the incoming stormwater runoff, (2) resuspension of accumulated sediment during subsequent storms, (3) inaccuracy in the analytical method used to measure TSS, and (4) ineffectiveness of the particular treatment technology.  Despite the low monitored TSS removal rates, sediment accumulation consistently increased throughout the test period at Downstream Defender and Vortechs units.  The depth of sediment in the sump of each unit was measured after each storm event.  Re-suspension of previously deposited material did not appear to be a problem during the test period.  Due to a relatively short test period and low TSS in the untreated runoff, sediment accumulation in the Stormceptor unit did not increase markedly with each sampling event.  Removal of other particulate bound pollutants like total metals and total phosphorus should be consistent with TSS.  All three BMPs achieved very low removals for total metals (less than 10 percent) and total phosphorus (less than 5 percent). None of the BMPs tested are expected to be effective in removing dissolved pollutants (that is, dissolved metals and soluble reactive phosphorus), because these systems function primarily as sedimentation devices. All three BMPs achieved positive removals for TPH-motor oil (ranging from about 60 to 70 percent and from 45.6 to 63 percent for the full and reduced data sets, respectively).  The timing of the grab sampling used to capture samples, however, may have biased the magnitude of this performance.  The methodology used for sampling TPH targeted sample collection at the beginning of each event, when the TPH concentration at the inlet was at its highest Due to the less than stellar overall performance of these stormwater treatment devices, SPU has determined that these devices are not cost effective and is not recommending their use for general purpose stormwater system retrofits in the City of Seattle.

The protected ground waters represent the exclusive source of drinking water for approximately 30,000 inhabitants of the Gig Harbor peninsula and Fox Island.  The project scope of work includes efforts to protect ground water resources from the impacts of significant sources of contamination and to develop a viable funding option to support ongoing pollution control efforts, while promoting greater public recognition of the importance of ground water resources.
column2: Prupose:  To preserve the quality of ground water within the Gig Harbor WMA by implementing critical elements of the Gig Harbor Ground Water ManagementProgram.  These elements included:  Preventing degradation of ground water quality through monitoring and source control efforts, raising the levels of public awareness concerning the need for protecting ground water resources, and assisting in the establishment of a long term, local financial support for ground water protection efforts. Results:  1) Addressed current conditions relating to, and extent of seawater intrusion areas along the Gig Harbor Peninsula.  2) Developed seawater intrusion control regulations regarding the number and location of wells within impacted areas.  3)  Developed a long-term monitoring program.  4)  Established a citizen-run ground water action group to implement community education efforts. column1: The purpose of the project is to: Assess water quality impacts of individual farms and livestock operations and priority rank them.  Develop individual farm plans with landowners and provide technical assistance for implementation of agricultural BMPs.  Implement educational programs targeted to small farms and forest landowners.  Work to establish a permanent agricultural management practices technical assistance program that will continue implementation work with local funds.
