column1: Tacoma-Pierce County Health Department's project will implement selected actions recommended by the Penrose Point/Mayo Cove Water Quality Protection Plan.  The scope of work includes water quality monitoring and a sanitary survey to identify pollution sources; development of best management practices; and formation of an advisory committee to oversee the project.
column2: Purpose: To improve water quality in the Mayo Cove watershed and implement most of the action items in the 1992 Penrose Point/Mayo Cove water quality protection plan.  Failing on-site septic systems and improper agricultural practices would be identified and corrected, and storm drains would be modified to reduce fecal coliform loading to Mayo Cove. Results: 1) Water quality monitoring showed some deterioration in water quality in Mayo, Camp, and Picnic Creeks, as well as poor water quality in Lagoon Creek.  Following the removal of livestock from a farm the creek traverses, water quality in Private Creek now appears to meet state standards for fecal coliform bacteria.  Marine water sampling showed high fecal coliform counts in the inner cover in summer; 2) On the 47 developed shoreline properties near Mayo Cove, the recipient was able to dye test 20 on-site sewage systems.  Two were found to be failing.  These were repaired with assistance from Centennial Grant No. G9800215; 3) A citizen advisory committee was formed and met regularly from April 1996 to June 1999.  The committee assisted in obtaining community cooperation for water quality monitoring, sanitary surveys, and stom water improvements projects.  It provided input for surface water quality improvements in the Mayo Cove Watershed; 4) The two top priority stormwater projects, realigning a culvert under Lorenz Road, and installing swales along Delano road, were completed.  A third project will be completed without grants funds; 5) The Natural Resource Conservation Service identified three farms with potential to pollute Mayo Cove.  NRCS completed a farm plan for one of the three; one no longer has livestock; and the third changed the location of the horses during the wet season so they are away from the stream; 6) A brochure was completed by Evergreen Elementary School students to inform residents in a friendly way about the importance of water quality protection.  The brochurehas been printed and will be distributed after the grant expiration date using other funds; 7) Boater wastes are a significant source of contamination in the summer; Penrose Point State Park has requested that Washington State Dept of Parks and Recreation install a new, more durable boater waste pumpout station (the current one frequently malfunctional); 8) A final report describes accomplishments, problems, and recommendations for the future.

column1: The city of Bremerton will conduct a combined sewer overflow (CSO) quality characterization to assess the quality of the actual discharge from the 16 permitted CSO sites and measure the parameters in the receiving waters. These 16 sites discharge an estimated 50 million gallons of combined wastewater/stormwater every year into Sinclair Inlet and the Port Washington Narrows (which flows between Dyes Inlet and Sinclair Inlet).  This data will provide a baseline for measuring improvement as CSO construction projects are completed and best management practices are implemented, and will indicate the need to implement source control activities.
column2: CSO discharge samples were collected from fourteen of the sixteen CSO sites.  Results were compared to water quality criteria.  Marine acute criteria for copper, zinc, and fecal coliforms were exceeded most often.  Eighteen different organic contaminants were detected in CSO discharges.  Water quality criteria exist for six of the eighteen organic compounds.  No samples exceeded the marine acute criteria.  Pesticides and PCBs were not detected from five CSO samples taken.  Bremerton CSO water quality was compared to other point and non-point sources; including King County CSOs, the Bremerton Wastewater Treatment Plant effluent, and stormwater quality from a national study and a Bremerton study.  Bremerton CSOs are similar in water quality to King County CSOs.  Ammonia + nitrate-nitrogen was used as a tracer to estimate the percentage of wastewater in CSO discharges.  The wastewater loading for each CSO site was calculated.  Water quality of CSO site modification was evaluated in order to assess the change of water quality prior to and following site modification. The receiving water was monitored during two dry weather events and following two significant CSO events.  Total suspended solids, total phosphorus and fecal coliforms were detected at increased levels following CSO events. Mid-channel stations and near shore stations were compared for future monitoring purposes.  The City of Bremerton has established a CSO monitoring program.  These data provide a baseline of water quality for measuring the impact of changes in the wastewater collection system.  Results of this study provide valuable data in designing an efficient and effective future monitoring program.

column1: The purpose of the project, as described in the project description of the grant agreement, was as follows:  To offer assistance, by the Tacoma-Pierce County Health Department (TPCHD), to all waterfront and nearshore home owners (in the Rocky Bay area) in evaluating and, if necessary, repairing their septic systems.  The project was designed to provide a comprehensive, on-site evaluation of all septic systems with potential for impact on Rocky Bay, in addition to addressing known problem systems.  This approach was intended to provide encompassing and long lasting water quality improvements and reverse the trend of bacterial contamination of Rocky Bay so that the commercial shellfish growing area prohibited for shellfish harvest could be reopened.
column2: Overall, the project was undertaken by the TPCHD to expedite repair work on known nearshore septic system failures, and to locate and correct any new failures that may have occurred since a shoreline sanitary survey that was conducted in 1993 and 1994.  TPCHD offered free septic system review and dye testing to all waterfront and nearshore homeowners.  Owners of failing systems were eligible to apply for grants of 65 percent of the cost of repair design and installation.  A maximum grant of $11,000 per system was allowed each property owner.  Detailed Results: The grant agreement contained four tasks: 1. Project Admin & Mgmt - $5,200; 2. Public Notification - $2,052; 3. Identification of Failing Septic Systems - $25,115; 4. Septic System Repair Grants to Homeowners - $150,000.  Project Administration: The project was administered and managed effectively and all required submittals were received.  Public  Notification: Extensive public notification occurred, including brochures mailed and handed out to about 600 residents in the area, word of mouth, door-to-door fliers to about 100 residents in the Rocky Bay area, and a few directed letters to certain owners.  The assistance program was discussed at six Rocky Bay Action Team meetings that occurred during the course of this project.  Identification of Failing Septic Systems: Six systems were dye tested or reviewed for signs of failure.  One system was found to be failing by dye testing and one site did not have a failing septic system, but had a pit privy (outhouse) that was used during weekend visits.  The remaining systems dye tested/reviewed did not show signs of failure.  One property owner who had been reluctant to cooperate with TPCHD staff in the past did consent to a dye test.  Another choose to stop occupying his property, and two others continued to refuse to respond to requests for access, but were not located in areas where failures were suspected.  Septic System Repair Grants to Homeowners: Two systems known to be failing were repaired without dye testing.  Two new situations were also corrected.  It was originally expected that a total of up to 30 systems would be tested and up to 12 failing systems would be detected.  Increased owner awareness, which may have been a result of the sanitary survey work, and part time occupancy of many properties, resulted in far fewer systems being tested and determined to be failing than originally anticipated. Low numbers of failing on-site systems were determined, and some relatively inexpensive repairs resulted in far less expenditure of grant funds than was originally anticipated. Conclusions: The project attempted to provide property owners the highest possible cost share without committing local agency funds to subsidize repairs.  If structured differently, more project resources may have gone to sanitary survey work.  The project was successful in resolving two known failing waterfront systems and in locating two additional sites where the system was failing or problematic.  The project also made it easier to access one waterfront property owned by an individual who refused earlier efforts to dye test.  (That test showed the system functioning properly, but without the availability of grant funding for potential repair, the system's status may never have been determined.)  Repairs performed during this project have undoubtedly improved water quality in Rocky Bay.  In conjunction with improvement in stormwater practices in the nearshore areas, the repairs appear to have reversed much of the bacterial contamination that has impacted commercial shellfish harvest in the Bay.  Recent testing shows that water quality in the Bay seems to be improving.  Continued sampling is needed to track water quality and locate new sources as they develop. Project Manager Comment: This grant did not require, nor did the TPCHD feel it had (or currently has) the capability to dye test every system.  Many local health departments feel limited in their ability to test all systems in an area.  While some health departments feel they can inspect an individual system after they have solid evidence of a failure of that system, many of them feel there is no adequate mechanism to provide for a complete survey in a problem (or other) area.  Identifying surface failures can be difficult without easy site access, and sub-surface failures are difficult to identify without a dye test.  Some easier way to survey systems in general and identify sub-surface failures, as well as gain more effective access to identify surface failures, needs to be developed, and may be a good subject for a pilot project or some type of special/focused grant. Something needs to be done to more effectively protect public water from contamination by specific failing systems while respecting the desires for private property rights.

column1: The Bremerton-Kitsap County Health District will use this money to restore good water quality in Port Gamble Bay to allow the upgrade of recently closed commercial shellfish beds back to a classification level of "approved". column1: The Tacoma-Pierce County Health Department will use the money to conduct a sanitary survey of shoreline properties to identify failing on-site sewage systems in the Pierce County portion of Burley Lagoon and Purdy Creek and will provide financial assistance to nearshore property owners to repair failing on-site sewage systems. Grants for on-site sewage system improvements will be made to homeowners for approximately 70 percent of the cost of system repair or replacement.  This approach should provide water quality improvement in Burley Lagoon and, along with the efforts of other agencies, should help restore Burley Lagoon as a conditionally open commercial shellfish growing area.
column2: To advertise the project, staff met with a number of interested property owners and distributed information at the 1998 Key Peninsula Shellfish Festival.  Project flyers were also hand delivered to shoreline property owners. During the course of the project, 106 on-site sewage systems were dye tested and 9 failing systems were identified.  The Burley Lagoon On-Site Repair Project was successful at accomplishing the three original goals.  The identification and repair of nine failing on-site sewage systems improved the water quality in Burley Lagoon, decreased public health concerns for shoreline residents and contributed to the upgrade of much of the lagoon.  All performance requirements, financial vouchers, and maintenance of this project appeared to be submitted in a timely manner.  The project requested 3 extensions.  The first request was due to poor response to advertisement about the available monies.  The other two were approved to allow time to complete a sanitary survey and correct any on-site problems associated with that survey.

column1: There were three intended results of the Minter Bay On-Site Project: 1) improve water quality in the bay; 2) decrease public health concerns for shoreline residents; and, 3) if possible, lead to an upgrade of the DOH classification of Minter Bay.  It was anticipated that providing up to 70% of repair costs would be sufficient incentive for people with failing on-site sewage systems to step forward and request assistance.
column2: The Tacoma Pierce County Health Department (TPCHD) marketed availability of financial assistance to homeowners via flyers to shoreline property owners, meeting with interested property owners, and information distribution at the Key Peninsula Shellfish Festival.  TPCHD staff dye-tested the systems of cooperating landowners to determine if the systems were failing.  During the course of the project, a total of fifty-nine on-site sewage systems were surveyed and four were found failing. Staff collected water samples from seeps near non-participating residences in an attempt to obtain probable cause and conduct mandatory tests.  Only one of the samples exceeded TPCHD's action level.  This property was then dye tested but was not found to be failing, and no further action was taken. (High bacterial concentrations were attributed to wildlife).  TPCHD provided 70% of the cost of design and installation to repair or replace failing systems.  Two systems were repaired and two were replaced during the course of the project.  The first two goals of the project were met; to improve water quality in the bay and to reduce public health concerns for the shoreline residents.  It is not known yet if the third goal, to upgrade the classification status of shellfish beds, was attained.  The DOH has not sampled Minter Bay on a regular basis for a number of years since no significant source control activities had occurred.  With four failing on-site systems corrected, the TPCHD will ask that the DOH sample Minter Bay to assess whether an upgrade is possible

column2: The Kitsap Conservation District conducted a watershed stream assessment of the basin and completed a report entitled: Port Gamble Bay Watershed Stream Assessment. column1: The purpose of the project was to determine the extent of failing OSS near outer Quartermaster Harbor and to determine the appropriate solutions to the failing OSS problem.  The project evaluated the feasibility of both repair of on-site systems and off-site drainfields as treatment alternatives.  By educating and involving the shoreline communities, the project was intended to lead to the repair or replacement of failing OSS near outer outer Quartermaster Harbor.  The project also included a monitoring component to document levels of fecal contamination in sediments, shellfish and freshwater streams, and to help identify the sources of fecal contamination.
column2: The activities carried out under the grant have successfully met or exceeded the major project objectives enumerated above. 1.  Community Involvement.  Seattle/King County Department of Public Health (KCH) sent letters to 82 owners and 87 non-owner occupants of residences in the affected neighborhoods.  This mailing list was refined for subsequent mailings.  KCH held two community meetings and a presentation was made to the Vashon Community Council to discuss the project.  A fourth meeting is scheduled for December 2000.  A citizens advisory committee (CAC) was formed with volunteers at the first meeting.  The CAC met approximately every four to six weeks for the two years duration of the project, and the committee has additional meetings scheduled.  The CAC developed a set of recommended actions to begin or continue through 2001 focusing on implementation.  The CAC is interested in demonstrating the feasibility of one or more upland drainfields.  2. On-Site Technical Consultation.  Following the initial public meeting, KCH sent letters to 108 homeowners offering free septic system assessments and free workshops on Caring For Your Septic System.  Only three respondents requested the free assessments by KCH.  As an alternative, KCH contracted with a consultant to conduct an on-site sewage system study, with results reported primarily as statistics to encourage cooperation.  The consultant found that approximately 30% of the homes investigated had sewage discharging onto the beach.  The consultant's report concluded that while there may may be sites in the study areas that could support an OSS, all study areas would be better served with off-site drainfields, either individual or community.  The report included an assessment of potential off-site, upland drainfield locations.  3. Monitoring.  The project included water quality, sediment and shellfish monitoring focusing on beachfront communities in the outer Quartermaster Harbor area.  Results of the stream water quality sampling indicated relatively high daily variability in coliform concentrations, with moderate to levels of contamination.  The streams are not considered the primary source of fecal contamination to the shellfish areas because of low flows and variable results.  Consistently higher levels of fecal coliforms were found in previous sampling of bulkhead drains, which would be the primary discharge point of failing systems.  Fecal coliform levels in all butter clams exceeded the 14/100ml standard for commercial shellfish sale.  4. Educational Outreach.  KCH assembled existing educational information about OSS into an educational packet for community residents. These were handed out during six OSS workshops held on Vashon Island.  In addition, KCH distributed the packets as part of door to door educational program in the outer Quartermaster Harbor beachfront neighborhoods.  KCH left packets at 70 houses; 28 residents were home and KCH discussed the project and OSS maintenance with those who were interested.

column1: The immediate purpose of the project was to eliminate the inadequate Wollochet Harbor treatment plant by intercepting it to an existing larger municipal sewerage system at Gig Harbor. column2: The Wollochet Harbor treatment plant was eliminated. The preliminary estimate for this project, assuming the use of an outside contractor was $95,000.  The District used volunteer labor, their consultant (Gray & Osborne) donated an inspector and the District purchased the materials.  The approximate final cost for this portion was $25,000, a savings of $70,000.  The second part of the work accomplished through using STEP was the landscaping. column1: PURPOSE OF PROJECT:  THE PROJECT WAS UDNERTAKEN TO ASSESS THE IMPACT OF ON-SITE SEWAGE SYSTEMS ON SURFACE WATER QUALITY.  THE IDEA WAS TO DOCUMENT THE SIGNIFICANCE OF THE LATERAL MOVEMENT OF BACTERIAL CONTAMINANTS RELEASED FROM ON-SITE SEWAGE DISPOSAL SYSTEMS TO UNDERLYING PERCHED SEASONAL GROUND WATERS, AS A MECHANISM FOR THE TRANSPORT OF CONTAMINATION TO DOWNGRADIENT SURFACE WATER BODIES.
column2: THE PROJECT HAD THE FOLLOWING RESULTS:  THE STUDY INDICATED THAT THERE WAS POTENTIAL FOR HORIZONTAL MIGRATION OF FECAL COLIFORM BACTERIA FROM ON-SITE SEWAGE DISPOSAL SYSTEMS INTO PERCHED SEASONAL WATER TABLES IF THE LATERAL DISTANCE WAS 30 FEET ORLESS AND THE GROUND WAS UNDISTURBED. THE LENGTH OF TIME FOR POTENTIAL IMPAIRMENT WAS LESS THAN THREE MONTHS IN A GIVEN YEAR, WHEN THE WATER TABLE REACHED HIGH ENOUGH TO BE WITHIN ONE TO TWO FEET OF THE DRAINFIELD BOTTOMS. AT ONE SITE, WHERE A FOUNDATION FOOTING DRAIN WAS SITUATED DOWNGRADIENT OF AN OPERATING DRAINFIELD, DYE RELEASED INTO AN ON-SITE SYSTEM WAS RECOVERED FROM THE FOOTING DRAIN OUTFALL. THIS SHOWS THAT A SIGNIFICANT RISK OF SURFACE WATER CONTAMINATION MAY BE POSED AT NUMEROUS WATERFRONT SITES ON THE PENINSULA WHERE A SHALLOW SEASONAL WATER TABLE IS INTERCEPTED BY A FOOTING DRAIN, CUT BANK, OR ROADSIDE DITCH. THE RESULTS OF THIS PROJECT WILL BE USED IN BUILDING PERMIT REVIEW.

The assessments of nitrogen reducing technologies to address the dissolved oxygen problems, the various institutional options that exist to address water quality problems from wastewater, and potential policy tools (including economic incentives) that might be used were very fruitful endeavors.  The Hood Canal Coordinating Council anticipates the construction of a Paradise Bay community sewer treatment system within two years. That system will be an MBR system the most effective at removing nitrogen from treated effluent. That system will also be able to replace existing failing onsite systems that have problems passing pathogens and fecal coliform into groundwater, as well as nitrogen. This system will provide up to 280 connections. This accomplishment is a direct result funding from this grant.  The Hood Canal septic loan program was launched in March, 2007, by the Hood Canal Coordinating Council, to serve any business or individual with a failing onsite sewer treatment system in Jefferson, Kitsap or Mason Counties and on the Port Gamble S'Klallam and Skokomish Reservations. It will provide over $6,000,000 of public and private foundation funding to offer low interest loans to repair failing onsite systems, to assist communities in constructing community systems to decommission existing failing onsite systems. This is also a result of funding provided by this grant. It allowed HCCC to fund HCCC staff to do the research and work with the various parties to bring this program to fruition.  Information from the surveys can be used as a basis for new policy initiatives in the future to address wastewater and water quality in the watershed. HCCC staff helped advance Hoodsport-to Skokomish community sewage treatment facility planning forward with its community survey efforts. They also helped get the local government parties together and begin negotiations that resulted in a formal MOA between Mason County, Mason PUD #1 and the Skokomish Tribe. That MOA helps the parties coordinate planning efforts and administer state and federal facility planning and construction funds. This effort will ultimately result in a large community treatment system for a large area of lower Hood Canal. HCCC's participation in this process was directly facilitated by funding from this grant.

Completed sanitary surveys at all sampling locations where they detected elevated fecal results.2.	Completed dye tests at most sanitary survey areas where they were warranted. Educated homeowners about the proper care and maintenance of their OSS.Performance Items and Deliverables •	Identified 467 freshwater discharges in the study area and performed FC and nutrient monitoring at those discharges. •	Provided education to residents, through 51 sanitary surveys and 3 public meetings, about FC and nutrient impacts on Hood Canal, and actions individuals can take to limit their effect.•	Entered data into EIM.Additional Comments: Overall, this project was successful in identifying shoreline discharges along Hood Canal and collecting FC and nutrient water quality data.  Over 90% of initial samples taken met the extraordinary FC standard.  The recipient completed sanitary surveys and provided site specific pollution reduction and elimination techniques at 51 sites, in order to protect water quality along the shorelines of Hood Canal.The County had a difficult time making contact with residents during the study period and determined this type of project would be best executed during the summer months due to the high level of seasonal occupancy. column1: THIS IS AN INITIAL CHARACTERIZATION STUDY OF THE GROUND WATER RESOURCES AND QUALITY OF THAT RESOURCE.  PRINCIPAL AQUIFERS WILL BE EVALUATED BASED ON RELATIVE VULNERABILITY TO CONTAMINATION AND PROTECTION NEEDS.
column2: ADDITIONAL GROUND WATER DEVELOPMENT APPEARS FEASIBLE IN EASTERN JEFFERSON COUNTY.  WATER BUDGET ANALYSES INDICATE 20 TO 25 MILLION GALLONS PER DAY (MGD) IN ADDITION TO CURRENT WITHDRAWAL MAY BE FEASIBLE. THE GEOLOGIC AND WELL YIELD ASSESSMENTS INDICATE NO EXTENSIVE AREAS OF MODERATE OR HIGH YIELD AQUIFERS.  INSTEAD, MODERATE AND HIGH YIELD AREAS APPEAR TO BE LOCALIZED IN ZONES WHERE DEPOSITS OF PERMEABLE MATERIALS ARE LOCALLY EXTENSIVE.  THIS DISTRIBUTION OF WELL YIELDS INDICATE THAT AREAS FOR PREFERRED FUTURE DEVELOPMENT CANNOT BE IDENTIFIED BASED ON THE RESOLUTION OF THIS STUDY. AMALL AREA-SPECIFIC FEASIBILITY STUDIES ARE RECOMMENDED BEFORE WELL EXPLORATION AND DEVELOPMENT PROGRAMS ARE UNDERTAKEN.  AN ASSESSMENT OF AQUIFER SUSCEPTIBILITY AND AQUIFER VULNERABILITY INDICATES THAT MOST OF THE COUNTY LIES IN LOW TO MODERATE SUSCEPTIBILITY AND LOW VULNERABILITY AREAS.  THIS ASSESSMENT INDICATES THE CONDITIONS FOR THE UPPERMOST AQUIFER.  DEEPER AQUIFERS ARE OFTEN LESS SUSCEPTIBLE AND LESS VULNERABLE. THE ASSESSMENT INDICATES THE CONTY HAS LOW PROBABILITY OF SIGNIFICANT AQUIFER CONTAMINATION.  EXISTING WATER QUALITY DATA ARE SCARCE.  THE FEW DATA THAT ARE AVAILABLE INDICATE LIMITED WATER QUALITY PROBLEMS IN PUBLIC WATER SYSTEMS WITH IRON, MANGANESE, AND CHLORIDE CONTAMINATION.  NUMEROUS STUDIES HAVE DOCUMENTED HIGH CHLORIDE LEVELS IN GROUND WATER FROM PRIVATE WELLS IN JEFFERSON COUNTY. SEVERAL DATA GAPS WERE IDENTIFIED DURING THE COURSE OF THIS STUDY, INCLUDING, LACK OF POSITIVE LOCATION DATA FOR WELL LOGS, THE LACK OF USABLE WATER LEVEL DATA, THE LACK OF WATER QUALITY DATA, AND LACK OF DEEP HYDROGEOLOGIC DATA.  MUCH ADDITIONAL INFORMATION ON THE CHARACTERISTICS OF GROUND WATER IN THE COUNTY COULD BE GENERATED IF THESE DATA GAPS WERE RECTIFIED.  A WELLHEAD PROTECTION PROGRAM WILL BE REQUIRED WITHIN THE NEXT FEW YEARS.  ALL PURVEYORS DEPENDENT ON GROUND WATER AS A SOURCE SHOULD PLAN NOW FOR UNDERTAKING PROTECTION PROGRAMS FOR THEIR SOURCE(S).  THIS GROUND WATER CHARACTERIZATION REPORT WILL BE USEFUL AS INDIVIDUAL SOURCES ARE ANALYZED UNDER THIS PROGRAM.

column1: The purpose of this project is to implement a portion of the Lower Hood Canal Action Plan, which was developed to address the causes of nonpoint pollution in the Lower Hood Canal portion of Puget Sound and which recommends implementation strategies which improve water quality.  Specifically, this project will design and employ a water quality monitoring program to develop a comprehensive database, which currently does not exist for this area.  The project will use selected water quality parameters to study physical, chemical, and biological characteristics of the water resources of selected, representative reaches within and adjacent to the Skokomish Reservation.  The project will compile all past and current monitoring studies into a single water resource database.  This database will be compared to current state and federal water quality laws and standards. The project will also initiate a cooperative inter-agency process to ensure that this water quality monitoring program is conducted in a coordinated manner with other water quality monitoring efforts focusing on the Lower Hood Canal and Lower Skokomish River Basin.  The interagency monitoring effort fulfills one of the directives of the Lower Hood Canal Action Plan.
column2: Private wells on the reservation were monitored for several water quality parameters, including fecal coliform bacteria and nitrate.  Surface water quality parameters, including fecal coliforms, nitrates, nitrites, ortho-phosphate, total suspended solids, temperature, dissolved oxygen, chloride, conductivity and turbidity were measured in six marine sites near Hoodsport, Potlatch and Union, and in 26 freshwater or brackish sites in the Skokomish River, Enatai Creek, Purdy Creek, Vance Creek, Hunter Creek, Weaver Creek, and Skabob Creek.  Monitoring data was compiled into a data base.  A surface water quality report of the monitoring results was submitted.

column2: Purpose:  After 30 years with "approved" status, the Lilliwaup Bay shellfish beds were voluntarily closed in 1997 to avoid official donwgrade to "Prohibited" based on water quality data that showed elevated fecal coliform levels.  Failing onsite sewage systems are believed to be a main cause of the degraded water quality. Results:  1)  The Mason County Department of Health Services advertised availability of repair funds by a letter to all property owners.  Prooerty owners who failed to respond to the first letter were sent a follow-up letter.  Several were also contracted by phone or in person.  2)  The County also created a filer about the program and distributed it around the community.  3)  Of 41 properties identified in the project area, 14 gave permission for the county to conduct dye tests.  All properties but one were dye tested (the county was never able to schedule a time with the outstanding property owner).  Of the 29 properties that were not inspected, 8 have either no water or no septic.  4)  Properties that would not allow access for dye testing have been flagged in the county's database, & dye tests will be requested at the time of sale or application for building permits.  5)  Three failing septic systeme were replaced. One, a residential system, was affecting both salt and fresh water.  The Lilliwaup Motel had been served by a septic tank and seepage pit since 1975.  The system for the Lilliwaup Store and associated residence was surfacing onto the ground in January 2000.

column2: Jefferson County Public Health has begun the work of correcting inadequate and failing OSS within the Hood Canal watershed through this project with the goal of restoring recreational and shellfish harvest uses, preventing human illness, and indirectly preventing fish kills from low DO. Local citizens are better informed about the problems of human sewage in Hood Canal and how to prevent problems with and maximize the function of their OSS.  A template is now in place for completing the work of identifying and correcting failing OSS in this watershed and it can also be used elsewhere in Jefferson County. Documenting OSS in the county, beginning with sanitary surveys, will be addressed in the next steps. Loans are available to homeowners for OSS repair. It was learned that shoreline sampling and sanitary surveys work together to identify failing OSS and cannot be relied upon alone Also, surveys must extend further upslope then the immediate shoreline, and that sampling may need to occur in both summer and winter months to adequately address potential.   Having completed sampling at 234 locations in 20 miles of Hood Canal shoreline, the results showed that 2-3% of the locations had significant bacterial counts. It could be reasonably expected to see another 30 hot spots in the remaining 60 miles of shoreline, despite the fact that the area remaining includes some long stretches of uninhabited areas. These areas also contain a high percentage of residences with older and perhaps non-functioning OSS. There remains plenty of work to identify the hot spots and to follow-up with sanitary surveys and repairs when pollution sources are identified.

column1: THE JEFFERSON COUNTY PUBLIC HEALTH WILL USE THE MONEY TO COLLECT WATER QUALITY DATA AND TO IMPLEMENT BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES FOR ON-SITE SEWAGE SYSTEMS AND AGRICULTURAL PRACTICES THROUGHOUT THE DRAINAGE.
column2: Water Quality and Environmental Outcomes Average fecal coliform loading for the October-May period was substantially higher at most stations in 2007-08 than in 2009-10.  Loading was higher coming from the main stem than from the East Fork.  Naylor’s Creek was contributing to the main stem.  Jefferson County and the Conservation District (District) have been trying to locate the cause of the high fecal coliform levels on Naylor’s Creek and will continue to do so.  In regards to temperature data there appears to be no downward trend at any of the stations. Twelve septic systems were discovered to be failing.  Failures were corrected through enforcement of code violations by the County septic team.The District worked with landowners in the Chimacum Creek area to install 14,376 feet of stream fencing; four (4) off-stream water facilities installed; 48.7 acres of riparian buffer was planted; and over three (3) miles of stream channel had aquatic vegetation removed. (Grant funds were used to provide staff time to help landowners obtain necessary permits for the projects. The District used other funding sources for the actual BMP implementation.)Performance Items and Deliverables All data collected by the Recipient was entered into EIM. Research was done on 327 properties known or suspected to generate wastewater within 250 feet of streams in the project area.  253 sanitary surveys were completed.  The Recipient and District partnered and participated in public meetings, offered public workshops, and mailed newsletters.

column2: Water Quality and Environmental Outcomes Reductions in non‐point source pollution can be difficult to quantify at the level of individual land parcels. In general, a cumulative effect at the watershed level over the long‐term is the best test of pollution correction measures, and continued monitoring will need to be performed to assess performance on environmental outcomes.Water quality sampling was effective at screening the area for impacts from bacterial indicators of pathogens. Enough samples were collected to identify areas as hot spots in need of investigation. However, not enough samples could be taken to fully analyze trends in water quality. The shoreline surveys conducted in this project should be considered a snapshot in time that gives a picture of the bacterial levels at that point in time. Non‐point source pollution is notoriously difficult to trace. However, in at least one case bacterial high hits were traced directly to a failing OSS resulting in repairs and correction of the problem. In several other cases, high hits resulted in higher scrutiny of OSS in the area and even though one system couldn’t be implicated directly, improvements were made to OSS that may have been contributing.Performance Items and Deliverables The project successfully:•	Conducted sanitary surveys of 725 Hood Canal parcels within 500 feet of shoreline.•	Identified potential failing onsite septic systems (OSS) contributing fecal coliform bacteria at levels in excess of the water quality standard. •	Identified and recorded the functional status of OSS for 1,130 properties in the project area. •	Educated homeowners in project area and other interested persons on the proper operation and maintenance of OSS through surveys, direct contact, and four Onsite Septic System Care and Monitoring workshops.•	Facilitated the repair of nine failing OSS and 19 system upgrades.

column2: Water Quality and Environmental Outcomes The Recipient completed extensive water quality monitoring and 262 (out of 369) property surveys in the project area. The Recipient initiated corrective actions (either OSS repairs or agricultural BMP implementation) on a total of 12 properties. (Some BMPs were funded through other sources.) The Washington DOH upgraded the shellfish classification for Discovery Bay from Restricted to Approved.  The Recipient’s water quality monitoring “revealed a long-term improving trend as compared with historical data.”Performance Items and DeliverablesThis grant funded the installation of:•	One Livestock bridge (Ecology participated in 6’ of the cost or the difference of the total size of the crossing).•	3,662 feet of riparian fencing•	1 Solar powered stock watering trough•	2 stream crossingsTo complete the public education component of the project, the Recipient held public meetings at the beginning of the project, mid‐way through, and at project close. The Recipient also offered educational workshops for homeowners on On-site Septic System Care and Monitoring in the project area four times during the project period.  These workshops included a slideshow, handouts, hands‐on activities, and question-and-answer sessions.Additional Comments:Overall response to this project in the project area was quite positive. The Recipient intends to continue water quality monitoring through 2014 using federal funds. They are also looking for ways to fund ongoing pollution identification and correction work and to continue the education component of the project.

column1: This project will assess the ecology of three publicly accessible lakes that have experience toxic cyanobacterial blooms in the past two years leading to public health closures of these lakes. column2: Water Quality and Environmental Outcomes The grant agreement identifies one outcome for evaluation:•	Reduced blue-green algal blooms at Anderson Lake, Gibbs Lake, and Lake Leland.Because the recommendations resulting from this project have not been implemented, this outcome has not yet been achieved.Performance Items and Deliverables JCPH completed the monitoring and reporting required by this grant.Additional Comments:Using the monitoring data collected with this project, JCPH developed four basic recommendations for management of the target lakes:•	Changes need to be made to the aeration system currently in place in Anderson Lake. The system is no longer controlling the release of phosphorus from lake sediments to the water column.•	The Department of Fish and Wildlife should suspend stocking of fish in Anderson Lake until improvements are made to the aeration system.•	Anderson Lake should be treated with alum to remove phosphorus.•	Algal cell counts are not a good substitute for toxicity testing in these lakes.

column1: The Mats Mats Bay Water Quality Improvement Project is designed to identify nonpoint pollution sources of fecal coliform bacteria (FC) contamination entering Mats Mats Bay in order to prevent a commercial shellfish growing area downgrade.  The project will help property owners correct problems with their on-site septic systems (OSS) or animal wastes and ensure that all OSS and agricultural properties in the project area are not adversely impacting the marine water or shellfish beds.  The project includes shoreline surface water, drainage, and marine water sampling for fecal coliform bacteria, sanitary surveys of residence and properties along Mats Mats Bay, and property owner assistance for implementing best management practices (BMP).
column2: Water Quality and Environmental Outcomes Growing Area Report for 2011(from Washington Department of Health) indicates that the bay is no longer threatened with a downgrade of shellfish classification. Water quality monitoring revealed a long-term improving trend as compared with historical data.Performance Items and Deliverables The bulk of the project involved sampling for fecal coliform bacteria as an indicator of human pathogens in water, and conducting door-to-door sanitary surveys of onsite septic systems with the goal of identifying and correcting failing systems as well as provide education on septic system care and maintenance.The Recipient completed a Quality Assurance Project Plan for their monitoring efforts, completed the monitoring in accordance with that plan, and submitted the required data to Ecology’s Information Management system (EIM).The Recipient completed 152 sanitary surveys. Of the six on-site sewage systems that were failing, four were repaired, one property is no longer occupied, and one was identified near the end of this project and is in the process of being handled.In addition, the Recipient conducted all of the education and outreach described in Task 4 of the grant agreement:•	Held two informational meetings at the beginning of the project; two mid-project, and one at the end of the project. •	Distributed newsletters twice a year.•	Held four workshops on on-site sewage system maintenance.•	Conducted a post-educational event survey to assess its effectiveness.

column2: Water Quality and Environmental Outcomes With some caveats, initial sampling results have been favorable, demonstrating improved water quality discharges. The vault system changes have increased the volume of the pretreatment of stormwater. Water quality samples have generally shown contaminant levels lower than permit requirements, though not consistently. The Port will examine further refinement of this system to achieve more consistent reduction of contaminants.Performance Items and Deliverables The Port completed the following stormwater improvement activities: 1) Identified the contaminant source areas by collecting samples of the gravel surfaces throughout the boatyard for metals analysis (copper, lead, zinc); 2) removed the metals-impacted soil identified by the sampling process and disposed of the material appropriately (this work was not funded by the grant); and 3) designed and implemented stormwater treatment retrofit improvements.  The Port installed two Stormwater Rx Aquip® systems which use a sand filtration technology. The Port re-designed and improved a stormwater vault system to improve infiltration of stormwater and to improve water quality of the stormwater discharged.Additional Comments: Water quality samples have not shown consistent improvements, and there may be several reasons for this. One of the Aquip units has been impacted by the tide gate design, which may not seal completely, letting salt water flow into the system. The Port will complete further refinement of the sand filtration discharge system to improve the treatment system and to reduce the media replacement costs.

column1: The goals of this project are to demonstrate the effects of water quality degradation on the nearshore marine habitat with live video monitoring and traditional water quality monitoring techniques; and to increase public awareness of these effects through active volunteer monitoring programs and a public lecture series.
column2: The project resulted in the following: Worked with students and local citizen volunteers to conduct seagrass surveys, using underwater video techniques.  Survey results were used to create maps of distributions and estimate the basal area coverage in nearshore habitat between Point Hudson and the Port of Port Townsend Boat Haven, at the railroad trestle at the southern end of the Boat Haven, and at the mouth of Chimicum Creek.  Conducted beach seine observations (i.e., demersal fish abundance surveys) annually, using students and citizen volunteers to help with sorting, counting, measuring, and entering data.  Conducted coliform monitoring quarterly from both Boat Haven and the Point Hudson Marina.  Baseline water quality data was collected monthly from 15 stations in Port Townsend Bay.  All eighth grade students from the Port Townsend School District participated in the nearshore component of this program.  These "labs" had a hands-on component as well as an educational component.  The data collection and analysis was integrated into the eighth grade science and computer curriculum.  Chimicum High School marine biology students assisted with the monitoring of the offshore stations.  Beach observation/monitoring has been conducted weekly by volunteers at five sites in the study area.  Biannual meetings were held to inform volunteers about trends observed.  A weather station was installed in the Marine Science Center and monitored by volunteers.  Data was entered into a database and compiled into quarterly and annual reports.  Water quality monitoring data was made available to the public via the "Port Townsend Bay Marine Resource Monitoring Project 1900-2000" newspaper insert.  8,500 copies of this document were distributed.  Other outreach included public lectures emphasizing regional water quality and nearshore habitat issues, and a series of articles in the local newspaper.  Two papers were presented at the annual Puget Sound Research Conference.

column2: The project had the following results: An integrated aquatic plant managment plan was developed for Lake Leland.  The plan recommends the use of grass carp to control Brazilian elodea.  However, at this time, the Department of Fish and Wildlife prefer not to issue a permit for grass carp stocking.  In the meantime, individuals may control the plant around their docks by handpulling, cutting, or installing bottom barriers.  The use of Rodeo for the reed canary problem in the outlet of Leland Creek was approved.  As part of the grass carp stock permit stocking requirements, water quality samples were collected form the Lake inlets.  Oxygen levels were monitored for 24 hours within a dense Brazilian elodea bed, a native plant bed, and an open water site.  The presence of Brazilian elodea generally depressed oxygen levels at all depths.  The open water site maintained the highest oxygen levels with the native plant beds being intermediate.

column1: The goal of this project was to implement the agricultural actions identified in the Ecology approved Quilcene-Dabob Watershed Action Plan.  There were three major objectives:  1. Develop and implement an aggressive information and education program with the agricultural community as the target audience; 2. Provide technical assistance to the commercial and noncommercial farms within the Quilcene-Dabob watershed as well as other watersheds in the county; and 3. Provide financial assistance to landowners installing agricultural best management practices in the Qulcene-Dabob watershed.
column2: Results:  1. An information and education plan was developed.  Newsletters, model farm awards, model farm tours, steamside management workshop, and news releases were all implemented.  Most activities were well received by the target audience.  2. The primary objective of technical assistance was to provide help to individuals to solve or prevent nonpoint source water pollution problems associated with agriculture.  Seventy-five percent of the time spent on this task was dedicated to the Quilcene-Dabob Bay's watershed and the other 25 percent of the time was spent in the other watersheds of East Jefferson County.  A total of six conservation plans were developed during the grant period, and three more are in the process of development.  Six of the plans are in the Quilcene-Dabob and three are in other watersheds of the county.  Best management practices (BMPs) ranged from stream fencing, pasture management, animal waste management, and roof runoff management.  3. The final objective was to develop a mechanism by which state funds could be used for the implementation of agricultural BMPs on private farms.  The Recipient was to design a BMP matrix that would detail landowners, acreage, BMPs, cost per BMP, and schedule for implementation.  Since there was not enough money in this project for actual implementation, the information would be used for a future Centennial Clean Water Fund application for BMP implementation.  However, Jefferson County the USDA Agricultural Stabilization and Conservation Service (ASCS) program had readily available cost-sharing funds that is used for BMP implementation on an individual basis.  The District and landowners opted to stay with the ASCS program, so the funds targeted for the BMP matrix was reassigned to technical assistance. The combination of state funded technical assistance and federally funded BMP implementation seemed to work successfully.  There were approximately 275 acres of farm land that has been treated by conservation planning. The extent of water quality improvements will not be known for several years.  Jefferson County Planning has a water quality monitoring program through which improvements in the county waters will be recorded.
